http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A measured characteristic of an entity is one that is measurable within the physical world. A measured characteristic includes primary and derived physical dimensions (e.g., length, mass, area, density). The measured value assigned to a measured characteristic may be a quantity (a numerical value) or a quality (a category), including both nominal and ordinal categories.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Recommended practice is to identify the resource by means of a string conforming to an identification system. http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: A related resource that is referenced, cited, or otherwise pointed to by the described resource.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Recommended practice is to describe the date, date/time, or period of time as recommended for the property Date, of which this is a subproperty.

Recommended practice is to refer to the subject with a URI. If this is not possible or feasible, a literal value that identifies the subject may be provided. Both should preferably refer to a subject in a controlled vocabulary.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: A topic of the resource.
A name given to the resource.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A keyword is a descriptor in which the association of the word with the entity facilitates information retrieval.
The unit expected for measurement entries.
An upper boundary for accepted numerical values.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: May be used for eliminating invalid data. This boundary may constrain a range of values of meaningful orders of magnitude, or constrain entries to positive values.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A lower boundary for accepted numerical values.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: May be used for eliminating invalid data. This boundary may constrain a range of values of meaningful orders of magnitude.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A short, unambiguous definition of the trait as used in the specific study context; may refer to a method of measurement; may copy the description of a public trait ontology;

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: The definition should make use of terms provided by existing public ontologies, e.g. the mass (PATO:mass), either fresh or dried, of a fruit (PO:fruit)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Unique identifier of the trait according to a public ontology, or a user-provided thesaurus of traits.
Type of trait values. Possible entries are numeric, integer, categorical, ordinal, logical, or character.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Numerical values represent measurements of length, volumes, ratios, rates or timespans. Integer values apply to count data (e.g. eggs per clutch). Binary data (encoded as 0 or 1) or logical data (coded as TRUE or FALSE) may apply to qualitative traits such as specific behavior during mating (e.g. are territories defended) or specialization to a given habitat (e.g. species restricted to relicts of primeval forests). Categorical traits should define a constrained set of factor levels, such as sex differences in wing morphology (both sexes winged, both sexes unwinged, only males winged, only females winged) or unconstrained entries such as color. Ordinal categorical traits may be better encoded as integer values, e.g. a logical sequence as in the case of life stages or hibernation stages, or habitat preference traits such as horizontal stratum use.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: An alternative lexical label for a resource.
Relates a concept to a concept that is more general in meaning.
A note about a modification to a concept.

skos:closeMatch is used to link two concepts that are sufficiently similar that they can be used interchangeably in some information retrieval applications. In order to avoid the possibility of compound errors when combining mappings across more than two concept schemes, skos:closeMatch is not declared to be a transitive property.
Relates a resource (for example a concept) to a concept scheme in which it is included.
Relates two concepts coming, by convention, from different schemes, and that have comparable meanings

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: These concept mapping relations mirror semantic relations, and the data model defined below is similar (with the exception of skos:exactMatch) to the data model defined for semantic relations. A distinct vocabulary is provided for concept mapping relations, to provide a convenient way to differentiate links within a concept scheme from links between concept schemes. However, this pattern of usage is not a formal requirement of the SKOS data model, and relies on informal definitions of best practice.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Relates a concept to a concept that is more specific in meaning.
A general note, for any purpose.
The preferred lexical label for a resource, in a given language.
skos:relatedMatch is used to state an associative mapping link between two conceptual resources in different concept schemes.
A note that helps to clarify the meaning and/or the use of a concept.
Links a concept to a concept related by meaning.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: AusTraits is an open-source, harmonized database of Australian plant trait data. It synthesises data on nearly 500 traits across more than 30,000 taxa from field campaigns, published literature, taxonomic monographs, and individual taxon descriptions. Begun in 2016 as an initiative between three lab groups, it has grown to be the largest collation of plant trait data for Australian plants. AusTraits integrates plant trait data collected by researchers from diverse disciplines, including functional plant biology, plant physiology, plant taxonomy, and conservation biology. By harmonizing and error checking values, linking all AusTraits data entries to detailed metadata, and documenting trait and trait values definitions, AusTraits is a resource researchers can trust and use for their research agendas with minimal additional filtering or manipulations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: AusTraits is an open-source, harmonized database of Australian plant trait data. It synthesises data on nearly 500 traits across more than 30,000 taxa from field campaigns, published literature, taxonomic monographs, and individual taxon descriptions. Begun in 2016 as an initiative between three lab groups, it has grown to be the largest collation of plant trait data for Australian plants. AusTraits integrates plant trait data collected by researchers from diverse disciplines, including functional plant biology, plant physiology, plant taxonomy, and conservation biology. By harmonizing and error checking values, linking all AusTraits data entries to detailed metadata, and documenting trait and trait values definitions, AusTraits is a resource researchers can trust and use for their research agendas with minimal additional filtering or manipulations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Plant that is photosynthetic but augments its energy, mineral nutrition, and /or water supply through parasitism. http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Species which germinate in damp or flooded conditions and can grow in or our of water.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Species which germinate in flooded conditions, grow in both flooded and damp conditions, reproduce above the surface of the water, and which have morphological plasticity (e.g. heterophylly) in response to water-level variation. (Morphologically plastic species; ARp)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Species which germinate in flooded conditions, grow in both flooded and damp conditions, reproduce above the surface of the water, and which have morphological plasticity (e.g. heterophylly) in response to water-level variation. (Morphologically plastic species; ARp)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A plant whose leaves form a distinctly large basal tuft or rosette, including large acaulescent monocots and cycads.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A plant whose leaves form a distinctly large basal tuft or rosette, including large acaulescent monocots and cycads.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Plant that climbs up another plant's stem or branches, rather than being able to support itself. Term used only if datasets do not specify if a climbing plant is herbaceous (a vine) or woody (a liana).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Plant that climbs up another plant's stem or branches, rather than being able to support itself. Term used only if datasets do not specify if a climbing plant is herbaceous (a vine) or woody (a liana).

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Herbaceous plant that climbs up another plant's stem or branches, rather than being able to support itself. This is usually synonymous with `vine`. Types of climbers (scrambling, twining) are captured under the trait `plant_climbing_mechanism`. (Synonyms, vine)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Herbaceous plant that climbs up another plant's stem or branches, rather than being able to support itself. This is usually synonymous with `vine`. Types of climbers (scrambling, twining) are captured under the trait `plant_climbing_mechanism`. (Synonyms, vine)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Woody or thick-stemmed (>2 cm) plant that climbs up another plant's stem or branches, rather than being able to support itself. This is usually synonymous with `liana`. Woody climbers generally use hooks, tendrils, and/or adventitious roots to climb; the climbing mechanisms used by a taxon are captured under the trait `plant_climbing_mechanism`. (Synonyms, liana)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Woody or thick-stemmed (>2 cm) plant that climbs up another plant's stem or branches, rather than being able to support itself. This is usually synonymous with `liana`. Woody climbers generally use hooks, tendrils, and/or adventitious roots to climb; the climbing mechanisms used by a taxon are captured under the trait `plant_climbing_mechanism`. (Synonyms, liana)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A taxonomic grouping that includes acaulescent ferns; ferns are vascular plants that reproduce via spores and have neither seeds nor flowers.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A taxonomic grouping that includes acaulescent ferns; ferns are vascular plants that reproduce via spores and have neither seeds nor flowers.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Subcategory of herb, specifically referring to plants that survive the winter/dry season as an organ (rhizome, bulb, corm, or tuber) buried in dry soil, with all leaves dying back each year.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Subcategory of herb, specifically referring to plants that survive the winter/dry season as an organ (rhizome, bulb, corm, or tuber) buried in dry soil, with all leaves dying back each year.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Herbaceous plant with a grass-like morphology that is within the order Poales. Taxa both with and without a tussock form are mapped to this term. This term is most frequently applied to three large monocot families, Poaceae, Cyperaceae, and Juncaceae, but the term could apply to other taxa within Poales with a grass-like morphology, including narrow, linear leaves and non-showy flowers, including Restionaceae, Centrolepidaceae, Anarthriaceae, and Ecdeiocoleaceae. Taxa outside Poales with a grass-like morphology should be designated as `herbs` and also have the term `tufted` mapped to the trait `stem_growth_habit`.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Herbaceous plant with a grass-like morphology that is within the order Poales. Taxa both with and without a tussock form are mapped to this term. This term is most frequently applied to three large monocot families, Poaceae, Cyperaceae, and Juncaceae, but the term could apply to other taxa within Poales with a grass-like morphology, including narrow, linear leaves and non-showy flowers, including Restionaceae, Centrolepidaceae, Anarthriaceae, and Ecdeiocoleaceae. Taxa outside Poales with a grass-like morphology should be designated as `herbs` and also have the term `tufted` mapped to the trait `stem_growth_habit`.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A subcategory of graminoid, indicating a plant which explicitly lacks a tussock morphology, with the leaves not growing in tufts.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A subcategory of graminoid, indicating a plant which explicitly lacks a tussock morphology, with the leaves not growing in tufts.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A seed-bearing plant which does not have a woody above-ground stem; when available this term has been divided into more detailed terms. (Synonyms, forb)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A seed-bearing plant which does not have a woody above-ground stem; when available this term has been divided into more detailed terms. (Synonyms, forb)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Plant that grows as a dense mound up to 1 metre in height. The term generally applies only to species within the genera Triodia that form such mounds and these are considered a distinctive and uniquely Australian growth form.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Plant that grows as a dense mound up to 1 metre in height. The term generally applies only to species within the genera Triodia that form such mounds and these are considered a distinctive and uniquely Australian growth form.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A taxonomic grouping that includes quillworts, clubmosses, and spike mosses.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A taxonomic grouping that includes quillworts, clubmosses, and spike mosses.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Refers to Eucalyptus species which are small trees that form a large lignotuber. They have multiple stems arising at or near ground level and regenerate from the lignotuber following fire.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Refers to Eucalyptus species which are small trees that form a large lignotuber. They have multiple stems arising at or near ground level and regenerate from the lignotuber following fire.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Plant that bears a rosette-like canopy of typically large, often compound leaves atop a usually thick (pachycaulous), columnar, unbranched or little-branched stem. Palms, tree ferns, trunked cycads, trunked grass-trees, and Pandanus are mapped to this term. (Synonyms, rosette-tree, palm, grass-tree)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Plant that bears a rosette-like canopy of typically large, often compound leaves atop a usually thick (pachycaulous), columnar, unbranched or little-branched stem. Palms, tree ferns, trunked cycads, trunked grass-trees, and Pandanus are mapped to this term. (Synonyms, rosette-tree, palm, grass-tree)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A woody plant that is distinguished by NOT being a tree, due to one of more of the following characteristics, 1) they are less than 8 metres in height; 2) if a plant community includes trees, the shrubs are shorter than the surrounding trees and not part of the canopy; 3) in comparison to trees, the leaves are more distributed along the entire trunk; 4) the plant has multiple relatively narrow stems arising at or near ground level. The definition of `shrub` is complex, as there are many single-stemmed shrubs within Australia and many taxa that are described in the taxonomic literature as a shrub or small tree.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A woody plant that is distinguished by NOT being a tree, due to one of more of the following characteristics, 1) they are less than 8 metres in height; 2) if a plant community includes trees, the shrubs are shorter than the surrounding trees and not part of the canopy; 3) in comparison to trees, the leaves are more distributed along the entire trunk; 4) the plant has multiple relatively narrow stems arising at or near ground level. The definition of `shrub` is complex, as there are many single-stemmed shrubs within Australia and many taxa that are described in the taxonomic literature as a shrub or small tree.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A plant that is only woody at the base, with the remainder of the stems regenerating yearly. This term is not meant to encompass short-lived plants that are only borderline woody. (Synonyms, suffrutescent)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A plant that is only woody at the base, with the remainder of the stems regenerating yearly. This term is not meant to encompass short-lived plants that are only borderline woody. (Synonyms, suffrutescent)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A tall, woody, perennial plant, usually with a single main trunk, and its leaves predominantly elevated above the ground surface.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A tall, woody, perennial plant, usually with a single main trunk, and its leaves predominantly elevated above the ground surface.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A sharp-pointed structure, which is a modified leaf or leaf part, including petioles, midribs, secondary veins, leaflets, or stipules.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: delta13C is calculated as the ratio of, 13C/12C in a sample to 13C/12C in a standard, minus 1. http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Maximum width dimension of a plant's vegetative canopy for a taxon in a given location; this is the larger width dimension and is orthogonal to its height and breadth.

A whole plant morphology trait [TO:0000398] which is the maximum [NCIT:C25564] width [PATO:0000600] dimension of a plant canopy [ENVO:01001242] for a taxon [NCIT:C40098] in a given population [PCO:0000001] or location [NCIT:C25341]. This is a plant's larger [NCIT:C49508] width dimension and is orthogonal to its height and breadth.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Maximum width dimension of a plant's vegetative canopy for a taxon in a given location; this is the larger width dimension and is orthogonal to its height and breadth.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Crown (canopy) width [TRY:325] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait is not meant to document the width of all individuals sampled, but instead the maximum width for a typical mature individual within a population or across a taxon.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Shortest width dimension of a plant's vegetative canopy; orthogonal to its height and width.
A whole plant morphology trait [TO:0000398] which is the smaller [NCIT:C25376] width [PATO:0000600] dimension of a plant canopy [ENVO:01001242].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Shortest width dimension of a plant's vegetative canopy; orthogonal to its height and width.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait is not meant to document the breadth of all individuals sampled, but instead the maximum breadth for a typical mature individual within a population or across a taxon.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Maximum vertical height of the vegetative shoot system for a taxon in a given location.

A whole plant morphology trait [TO:0000398] which is the maximum [NCIT:C25564] vertical [PATO:0001854] height [PATO:0000119] of the vegetative shoot system [PO:0025607] for a taxon [NCIT:C40098] in a given population [PCO:0000001] or location [NCIT:C25341].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Maximum vertical height of the vegetative shoot system for a taxon in a given location.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: MaxStemHeight_m [PalmTraits] (https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-019-0189-0)
exact match: Average height [BROT:10] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
related match: minimum whole plant height [BIEN] (https://bien.nceas.ucsb.edu/bien/biendata)
exact match: whole plant height [BIEN] (https://bien.nceas.ucsb.edu/bien/biendata)
exact match: maximum whole plant height [BIEN] (https://bien.nceas.ucsb.edu/bien/biendata)
exact match: Plant_height_max [GIFT:1.6.2] (https://gift.uni-goettingen.de)
exact match: Plant height vegetative [TRY:3106] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
exact match: Plant height vegetative [TOP69] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait is not meant to document the height of all individuals sampled, but instead the maximum height for a typical mature individual within a population or across a taxon. The trait should only be scored for self-supporting plants, not climbers whose height is dependent on the surrounding vegetation. The documented height should be the maximum height achieved by vegetative shoots, not the height reached by reproductive shoots, as it represents the plant's access to light.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Maximum diameter at breast height (DBH) for a taxon in a given location. It is commonly referred to as 'DBH'.

A stem morphology trait [TO:0000361] which is the maximum [NCIT:C25564] diameter at breast height [ECSO:00000549] for a taxon [NCIT:C40098] in a given population [PCO:0000001] or location [NCIT:C25341].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Maximum diameter at breast height (DBH) for a taxon in a given location. It is commonly referred to as 'DBH'.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: MaxStemDia_cm [PalmTraits] (https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-019-0189-0)
exact match: diameter at breast height (1.3 m) [BIEN] (https://bien.nceas.ucsb.edu/bien/biendata)
exact match: DBH_max [GIFT:1.8.2] (https://gift.uni-goettingen.de)
exact match: Stem diameter [TRY:21] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait is always meant to be measured at 'breast height', 1.4 m above the ground surface. However, for short plants this will not always be the case, so it is advised to read the methods to confirm at what height plant diameters have been recorded. This trait is not meant to document the DBH of all individuals sampled, but instead the maximum DBH for a typical mature individual within a population or across a taxon.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Count of stems on multi-stemmed plants.
A shoot system morphology trait [TO:0000077] which is the count [NCIT:C25463] of stems [PO:0009047] on multi-stemmed plants [PO:0000003].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Count of stems on multi-stemmed plants.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Plant biomass and allometry: Shoots per plant [TRY:1034] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Maximum vertical height of the vegetative shoot system of a non-self-supporting taxon (i.e. a vine, liana, or other climbing plant) in a given location.

A whole plant morphology trait [TO:0000398] which is the maximum [NCIT:C25564] vertical [PATO:0001854] height [PATO:0000119] of the vegetative shoot system [PO:0025607] of a climbing plant that is not self-supporting and therefore has a height that depends on the surrounding vegetation.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Maximum vertical height of the vegetative shoot system of a non-self-supporting taxon (i.e. a vine, liana, or other climbing plant) in a given location.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: related match: Average height [BROT:10] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
related match: Plant height [TRY:18]  (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: While this trait is intended to indicate the height of climbing plants, the height of an epiphyte relative to the soil surface could also be documented here. All heights reported for this trait will be dependent on the height of the surrounding vegetation.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#scop.@value: applicable to plants that are not self-supporting

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Maximum vertical height of the reproductive shoot system for a taxon in a given location.
A whole plant morphology trait [TO:0000398] which is the maximum [NCIT:C25564] vertical [PATO:0001854] height [PATO:0000119] of the reproductive shoot system [PO_0025082].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Maximum vertical height of the reproductive shoot system for a taxon in a given location.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: related match: Plant height [TRY:18]  (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait can be scored for any species, but is intended as an alternative to `plant_height` (maximum vegetative height) for species that do not have vegetative stems, but instead only leaves and reproductive stems that extend past the soil surface.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Maximum length or extent of a plant's stems.
A shoot system morphology trait [TO:0000077] which is the maximum [NCIT:C25564] length [PATO_0000122] of a plant's stems [PO_0009047].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Maximum length or extent of a plant's stems.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Stem length [TRY:326]  (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait can be scored for any species, but is intended as an alternative to `plant_height` (maximum vegetative height) for species that are prostrate, crawling, creeping or similar.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Degree to which a plant is defended by spines, thorns and/or prickles, as defined by P<U+00C3><U+00A9>rez-Harguindeguy et al. 2013.

A plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839] which summarises the extent of physical structures a plant uses for defence [NCIT:C61556], including the size [PATO:0000117], strength [PATO:0001230], and density [PATO:0001019] of spine leaves [PO:0025173], spine stipules [PO:0025174], thorns [PO:0025172], and/or prickles [PO:0025169] and the pain [HP:0012531] inflicted by these structures.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Degree to which a plant is defended by spines, thorns and/or prickles, as defined by P<U+00C3><U+00A9>rez-Harguindeguy et al. 2013.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Armature [PalmTraits] (https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-019-0189-0)
close match: Spinescence [BROT:21] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
close match: Leaf emergences (pubescence, pruinescence, hairs, spines, thorns) [TRY:677] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: The values for this trait are exactly those defined by P<U+00C3><U+00A9>rez-Harguindeguy et al. 2013 (doi:10.1071/BT12225). See the trait `plant_physical_defence` for individual plant structures a plant uses for physical defence.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between embryos that are green versus colourless.
A plant embryo cotyledon morphology trait [TO:0000775] which is the colour [PATO:0000014] of the plant embryo cotyledon [PO:0025470].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between embryos that are green versus colourless.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between cotyledons that function as leaves and can photosynthesise versus ones that function as energy reserve organs.
A plant embryo morphology trait [TO:0000064] which indicates if the cotyledons [PO:0020030] have a photosynthesis [GO:0015979] or energy [PATO:0001021] storage [OBI:0302893] function [NCIT:C25518].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between cotyledons that function as leaves and can photosynthesise versus ones that function as energy reserve organs.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between seedlings where the cotyledon remains within the seed coat versus emerges from the seed coat at germination.
A plant embryo morphology trait [TO:0000064] which indicates if the cotyledons [PO:0020030] emerge from the seed coat [PO:0009088] at germination [GO:0009845].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between seedlings where the cotyledon remains within the seed coat versus emerges from the seed coat at germination.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between glabrous versus hairy cotyledons.
A plant embryo cotyledon morphology trait [TO:0000775] which is the pilosity [PATO:0000066] of the cotyledons [PO:0020030].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between glabrous versus hairy cotyledons.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between glabrous versus hairy hypocotyls, where the hypocotyl is the embryonic axis to which the cotyledons are attached.
A seedling hypocotyl morphology trait [TO:0000769] which is the pilosity [PATO:0000066] of the hypocotyl [PO:0020100].

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between seedlings where the first leaf is scale-like (cataphyll) versus leaf-like.

A plant embryo true leaf formation stage [PO:0001095] morphology trait which is whether the leaf [PO:0025034] at the first stem node [PO:0020141] above the epicotyl [PO:0020035] in a true leaf or a scale leaf.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between seedlings where the first leaf is scale-like (cataphyll) versus leaf-like.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between seedlings where the leaves at the first node are single versus paired.
A plant embryo true leaf formation stage [PO:0001095] morphology trait which is the leaf count [NCIT:C25463] at the first stem node [PO:0020141] above the epicotyl [PO:0020035].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between seedlings where the leaves at the first node are single versus paired.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between seedlings that germinate above versus below ground.
A plant embryo cotyledon morphology trait [TO:0000775] which is the position [PATO:0000140] of seed germination [GO:0009845] relative to the soil surface.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Binary variable distinguishing between seedlings that germinate above versus below ground.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The 2-dimensional projected (scanned) area of the surface of a leaf or a leaf analogue (leaflet, cladode, phyllode).

A leaf area trait [TO:0000540] which is the 2-D [PATO:0001709] area [PATO:0001323] of the leaf lamina [PO:0020039] and petiole [PO:0020038]. For some species the area of a leaf analogue is reported, possibly a leaflet [PO:0020049], cladode [PO:0025354], or phyllode [PO:0025335].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The 2-dimensional projected (scanned) area of the surface of a leaf or a leaf analogue (leaflet, cladode, phyllode).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait includes measurements of leaves and leaf analogues, including leaflets, cladodes, and phyllodes. When a measurement is made on a leaf analogue, the tissue measured should be documented as part of the methods or noted as a `context` or under `measurement_remarks`. Leaflet area can alternatively be mapped to the trait `leaflet_area`. It is most common for leaf area measurements to include the petiole; the measurement methods should indicate if the petiole is included in or excluded from the leaf area measurements. For terete leaves, leaf area should still be recorded as the 2-dimensional projected area.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The 2-dimensional projected (scanned) area of the surface of the lamina of a single leaflet.
A leaf area trait [TO:0000540] which is the 2-D [PATO:0001709] area [PATO:0001323] of a single leaflet [PO:0020049] lamina [PO:0025060]. This measurement will not include the petiole [PO:0020038].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The 2-dimensional projected (scanned) area of the surface of the lamina of a single leaflet.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Maximum width axis of a leaf or a leaf analogue (a leaflet, cladode, or phyllode), measured perpendicular to the leaf length.
The maximum [NCIT:C25564] width [PATO:0000921] axis of a leaf [PO:0025034] measured perpendicular to [PATO:0002434] the leaf length [PATO:0000122].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Maximum width axis of a leaf or a leaf analogue (a leaflet, cladode, or phyllode), measured perpendicular to the leaf length.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait refers to the single line marking the maximum width of the leaf lamina. For a compound leaf the correct measure is the maximum width of the total leaf blade. It is the width measure that will be reported in taxonomic treatments. It is not the `effective_leaf_width`, a trait that records the diameter of the largest circle that can be drawn within the leaf lamina. If a leaf analogue (leaflet, cladode, or phyllode) is measured instead of a true leaf, this should be noted as a `context` or under `measurement_remarks`.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Thickness of the leaf lamina, generally measured away from the midrib.
The thickness [PATO:0000915] of the leaf lamina [PO:0020039], measured away from the midrib [PO:0020139].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Thickness of the leaf lamina, generally measured away from the midrib.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: leaf thickness [BIEN] (https://bien.nceas.ucsb.edu/bien/biendata)

exact match: Leaf thickness [TOP20] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Leaf thickness measurements submitted from the ecological literature will generally avoid the midrib, but not avoid lower order leaf veins. In contrast, leaf thickness measurements from the taxonomic literature will usually include any veins or midribs, because in this literature leaf thickness is generally measured on succulent plants. The `methods` field should document whether the midrib was explicitly included, excluded, or ignored.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The oven dry mass of a leaf or leaf analogue (leaflet, cladode, phyllode).

When a measurement is made on a leaf analogue, the tissue measured should be documented as part of the methods or noted as a `context` or under `measurement_remarks`. Leaflet dry mass can alternatively be mapped to the trait `leaflet_dry_mass`. It is most common for leaf dry mass measurements to include the petiole; the measurement methods should indicate if the petiole is included in or excluded from the leaf dry mass measurements.

A leaf dry mass trait [TO:0001014] which is the dry mass of a single leaflet [PO:0020049]. This measurement will not include the petiole [PO:0020038].

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The fresh mass of a leaf or leaf analogue (leaflet, cladode, phyllode).

A leaf mass trait [TO:0000505] which is the mass [PATO:0000125] of a fresh [EnvThes:21976] leaf [PO:0025034], indicating its mass at the time it is picked. For some species the mass of a leaf analogue is reported, possibly a leaflet [PO:0020049], cladode [PO:0025354], or phyllode [PO:0025335].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The fresh mass of a leaf or leaf analogue (leaflet, cladode, phyllode).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: leaf fresh mass [BIEN] (https://bien.nceas.ucsb.edu/bien/biendata)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait includes measurements of leaves and leaf analogues, including leaflets, cladodes, and phyllodes. When a measurement is made on a leaf analogue, the tissue measured should be documented as part of the methods or noted as a `context` or under `measurement_remarks`. It is most common for leaf fresh mass measurements to include the petiole; the measurement methods should indicate if the petiole is included in or excluded from the leaf fresh mass measurements. A source of variation for this trait will be how leaves are stored and if they are partially rehydrated before weighing; these details should be documented in the methods.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Length of the petiole from the leaf base to the leaf axil.
Length [PATO:0000122] of the petiole [PO:0020038]), from the leaf base [PO:0020040] to the leaf axil [PO:0009023].

Width [PATO:0000921] of the petiole [PO:0020038].

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Maximum width axis of a single leaflet, measured perpendicular to the leaflet length.

A leaf morphology trait [TO:0000748] which is the maximum [NCIT:C25564] width [PATO:0000921] axis of a single leaflet [PO:0020049] measured perpendicular to [PATO:0002434] the leaflet length [PATO:0000122].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Leaf mass per area includes measurements submitted as `specific_leaf_area` (SLA); they are simply inverted. Leaf mass per area is explicitly measured on an entire leaf, including the petiole. Measurements made on a piece of the leaf lamina, excluding petiole and midrib, are a separate trait `leaf_lamina_mass_per_area`. If measurements are made on the entire leaf lamina, but the petiole is excluded, this should be noted in the methods or under `measurement_remarks`.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The ratio of leaf dry mass to leaf fresh volume.
The ratio [PATO:0001470] of leaf [PO:0025034] dry [PATO:0001824] mass [PATO:0000125] to leaf fresh [EnvThes:21976] volume [PATO:0000918].

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The ratio of total plant leaf area to total plant dry mass; LAR.

It is best practice for leaf area measurements to include the petiole.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The ratio of leaf dry mass to total plant dry mass.
A leaf mass trait [TO:0000505] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of a plant's total leaf dry mass [APD:glossary/40080] to total plant dry mass [TO:0000352].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The ratio of leaf dry mass to total plant dry mass.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The ratio of leaf dry mass to leaf fresh mass; LDMC.
A leaf mass trait [TO:0000505] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of leaf dry mass [TO:0001014] to leaf [PO:0025034] fresh mass [APD:glossary/40044].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The ratio of leaf dry mass to leaf fresh mass; LDMC.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Two similar traits are `leaf_water_content_per_dry_mass`, the ratio of leaf water content to leaf dry mass and `leaf_water_content_per_fresh_mass`, the ratio of leaf water content to leaf fresh mass.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The ratio of leaf fresh mass to leaf area, measured on an entire leaf including the petiole.

A leaf area trait [TO:0000540] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the leaf [PO:0025034] fresh mass [APD:glossary/40044]. to the leaf area [PATO:0001323], measured on an entire leaf, including the entire leaf lamina [PO:0020039] and the petiole [PO:0020038].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The ratio of leaf fresh mass to leaf area, measured on an entire leaf including the petiole.
