http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Leaf fresh mass per area is explicitly measured on an entire leaf, including the petiole.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Leaf fresh mass per leaf area

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The ratio of the mass of water in a fresh leaf (leaf water content) to leaf surface area; leaf succulence.
A leaf mass trait [TO:0000505] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the mass [PATO:0000125] of water [CHEBI:15377] in a fresh [EnvThes:21976] leaf [PO:0025034] to leaf area [PATO:0001323].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The ratio of the mass of water in a fresh leaf (leaf water content) to leaf surface area; leaf succulence.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Leaf water content per unit leaf area (leaf succulence)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The ratio of the mass of water in a fresh leaf (leaf water content) to leaf dry mass.
A leaf mass trait [TO:0000505] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the mass [PATO:0000125] of water [CHEBI:15377] in a fresh [EnvThes:21976] leaf [PO:0025034] to leaf dry mass [TO:0001014].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The ratio of the mass of water in a fresh leaf (leaf water content) to leaf dry mass.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Leaf water content per leaf dry mass (not saturated) [TRY:3120] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: A similar trait that is recorded by a greater number of studies is `leaf_dry_matter_content`, the ratio of a leaf dry mass to leaf fresh mass.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Leaf water content per unit leaf dry mass

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The ratio of the mass of water in a fresh leaf (leaf water content) to leaf fresh mass

A leaf mass trait [TO:0000505] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the mass [PATO:0000125] of water [CHEBI:15377] in a fresh [EnvThes:21976] leaf [PO:0025034] to leaf fresh mass [APD:glossary/40044].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The ratio of the mass of water in a fresh leaf (leaf water content) to leaf fresh mass

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: A similar trait that is recorded by a greater number of studies is `leaf_dry_matter_content`, the ratio of a leaf dry mass to leaf fresh mass.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Leaf water content per unit leaf fresh mass

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The ratio of the mass of water in a leaf (leaf water content) to the mass of a saturated leaf. A saturated leaf is one that has been hydrated to its maximal water holding capacity and is at full turgor.

A leaf mass trait [TO:0000505] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the mass [PATO:0000125] of water [CHEBI:15377] in a saturated leaf [PO:0025034] to the mass of a saturated leaf. A saturated leaf is one that has been hydrated to its maximum [NCIT:C25564] water holding capacity [IOBC:200906064703668091], known as full turgor [PATO:0001620].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The ratio of the mass of water in a leaf (leaf water content) to the mass of a saturated leaf. A saturated leaf is one that has been hydrated to its maximal water holding capacity and is at full turgor.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf water content per leaf dry mass (at saturation) [TRY:3122] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Leaf water content per unit saturated leaf mass

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The ratio of leaf cell wall dry mass to leaf dry mass. This is the fraction of cell wall material that can be recovered from total leaf biomass.
A leaf mass trait [TO:0000505] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of cell wall [GO:0009505] dry mass to leaf dry mass [TO:0001014].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The ratio of leaf cell wall dry mass to leaf dry mass. This is the fraction of cell wall material that can be recovered from total leaf biomass.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Leaf cell wall mass per leaf dry mass [TRY:3375] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Variable distinguishing between general leaf form (shape) categories.
A leaf shape trait [TO:0000492] which is inclusive [NCIT:C166400] categories describing the shape [PATO:0000052] of a leaf [PO:0025034] as broad, needle-like, or scale-like.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Variable distinguishing between general leaf form (shape) categories.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Basic leaf shape [BROT:5] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
exact match: Leaf_form_1 [GIFT:4.11.1] (https://gift.uni-goettingen.de)
related match: Leaf type [TRY:43] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
related match: Leaf form [TOP225] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Terms identifying the plant organ responsible for photosynthesis are mapped to the trait `plant_photosynthetic_organ`, while `leaf_form_general` only includes terms pertaining to the general form of the leaf. The trait `leaf_shape` provides detailed vocabulary to describe a leaf's shape.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Shapes of a leaf or leaflet.

A leaf shape trait [TO:0000492] which is the shape [PATO:0000052] and form of a leaf [PO:0025034], considering the ratio [PATO:0001470] of leaf length [PATO:0000122] to leaf width [PATO:0000921], the position [PATO:0000140] of the maximum [NCIT:C25564] width dimension relative to the length axis [NCIT:C25154], and the curvature [PATO:0001591] of the leaf margin [PO:0020128].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Shapes of a leaf or leaflet.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf shape [TRY:154] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
close match: Leaf form [TOP225] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait includes terms to describe the shape of leaves, regardless of if they are broad leaves, scale-like leaves, or needle-like leaves. For compound leaves, it is generally the shape of the leaflet that is recorded. See the trait `leaf_type` for broad terms referencing leaf form (broadleaf, needle, scale) and `plant_photosynthetic_organ` for terms indicating which plant organ or tissue functions as the plant's primary photosynthetic organ (e.g. phyllode, cladode, article).

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The shape of the basal margin of a leaf.

A leaf shape trait [TO:0000492] which is the variation in shapes and forms of a leaf base [PO:0020040], especially considering the curvature [PATO:0001591] of the leaf margin [PO:0020128] near where it attaches to the petiole [PO:0020038].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The shape of the basal margin of a leaf.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Shape of the leaf margin, referencing incisions or projections in the outermost 1/8 of the leaf lamina.

A leaf shape trait [TO:0000492] which is the edge shape [PATO:0002267] of the leaf margin [PO:0020128], in particular the presence or absence of leaf lamina teeth [PO:0025518] and the shape [PATO:0000052] of the leaf lamina teeth (serrate, dentate, or crenate).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Shape of the leaf margin, referencing incisions or projections in the outermost 1/8 of the leaf lamina.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Leaf_margin_1 [GIFT:4.12.1] (https://gift.uni-goettingen.de)
exact match: Leaf margin type [TRY:963] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Terms describing leaf lamina projections and incisions that are greater than 1/8 of the distance to the midrib are captured under the traits `leaf_lobation` and `leaf_division_detailed`.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The posture (curvature or curling) of the leaf margin.

A leaf shape trait [TO:0000492] which is the degree of curvature [PATO:0001591] or curling [PATO:0000405] of the leaf margin [PO:0020128] along the side of the leaf, at the leaf apex [PO:0020137], and at the leaf base [PO:0020040].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The posture (curvature or curling) of the leaf margin.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait captures the posture of the leaf margin, where posture refers to the placement of different parts of the leaf's margin relative to a flat plane. This trait's definition and allowable levels will be further refined once more data are available to map onto possible trait values.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A trait that indicates whether a leaf lamina or leaflets display any divisions or dissections on a 2-dimensional plane that extend greater than 1/8 of the distance to the midrib.
A leaf shape trait [TO:0000492] which is the presence or absence of leaf lamina lobes [PO:0025517] along the leaf margin [PO:0020128] and how far the lobes extend toward the midrib [PO:0020139].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A trait that indicates whether a leaf lamina or leaflets display any divisions or dissections on a 2-dimensional plane that extend greater than 1/8 of the distance to the midrib.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: For terms pertaining to 2-dimensional leaf lamina divisions and incisions that are less than 1/8 of the distance to the midrib, see the trait `leaf_margin`. See also the trait `leaf_division` for more detailed leaf lobation (and leaf compoundness) trait values. Note that there might be some species that grade from deeply lobed simple leaves to compound leaves.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A binary trait that indicates whether a leaf lamina is simple or divided into discontinuous leaflets (compound).
A leaf shape trait [TO:0000492] which is whether a leaf [PO:0025034] is a simple leaf [PO:0020042] or is divided into leaflets [PO:0020049] making it a compound leaf [PO:0020043].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A binary trait that indicates whether a leaf lamina is simple or divided into discontinuous leaflets (compound).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Leaf division degree [BROT:2]  (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
exact match: leaf compoundness [BIEN] (https://bien.nceas.ucsb.edu/bien/biendata)
exact match: Leaf compoundness [TRY:17] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
exact match: Leaf compoundness [TOP222] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: See also the trait 'leaf_division' for more detailed leaf compoundness trait values. Note that there might be some species that grade from deeply lobed simple leaves (see trait `leaf_lobation`)  to compound leaves.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A trait that captures the types of lobed leaves and compound leaves, including the arrangement of the lobes or leaflets relative to the midrib or other primary veins and the number of orders of axes across which there are incisions or divisions.

A leaf shape trait [TO:0000492] which indicates types [NCIT:C25284] of lobed leaves [PO:0025517] and compound leaves [PO:0020043], including the arrangement [NCIT:C61532] of the lobes or leaflets [PO:0020049] with respect to the midrib [PO:0020139] or other primary leaf veins [PO:0025413] and the number of orders of axes [NCIT:C25154] across which there are incisions or divisions.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A trait that captures the types of lobed leaves and compound leaves, including the arrangement of the lobes or leaflets relative to the midrib or other primary veins and the number of orders of axes across which there are incisions or divisions.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: related match: Leaf compoundness [TRY:17] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
related match: Leaf compoundness [TOP222] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait provides detailed description of leaf divisions, beyond what is captured in `leaf_compoundness` (simple versus compound) and `leaf_lobation` (entire versus lobed). The term 'divided' is meant to indicate lobing, such as 'trichotomously divided', but as 'divided' is also used in some context to indicate the divisions of leaves into leaflets, it is avoided as a trait value for this trait.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The maximum perpendicular height of a leaf when positioned on a flat surface.

A leaf shape trait [TO:0000492] which is the maximum [NCIT:C25564] perpendicular [PATO:0002434] height [PATO:0000119] of a leaf [PO:0025034] placed on a flat surface, indicating the 3-D extent [PATO:0001710] of the leaf. This generally corresponds with whether the leaf is curled [FLOPO:0010468].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The maximum perpendicular height of a leaf when positioned on a flat surface.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: A measure of how planar versus 3-dimensional a leaf is. The term posture refers to the placement of different parts of the leaf's lamina relative to a flat plane.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The 3-dimension shape of the surface of the leaf lamina, including its degree of curvature and bending.

A leaf shape trait [TO:0000492] which is the 3-D shape [PATO:0002266] of the surface [NCIT:C25245] of the leaf lamina [PO:0020039], including its degree of curvature [PATO:0001591] and whether it is bent [PATO:0000617].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The 3-dimension shape of the surface of the leaf lamina, including its degree of curvature and bending.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Variable describing whether mature adult phase leaves have a glaucous appearance, the colour due to being covered with a smooth, usually whitish to bluish epicuticular wax that can easily be rubbed off.

A leaf morphology trait [TO:0000748] which is the presence or absence of epicuticular wax [PO:0025388] on the leaf lamina [PO:0020039] of a fully expanded adult phase leaf [PO:0006340], giving the leaf lamina surface a white-coloured [PATO:0000014] or blue-coloured waxy [PATO:0002384] appearance, termed glaucous.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Variable describing whether mature adult phase leaves have a glaucous appearance, the colour due to being covered with a smooth, usually whitish to bluish epicuticular wax that can easily be rubbed off.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: The accompanying methods should specify if the trait was scored on the upper (adaxial) or lower (abaxial) surface of the leaf; in the absence of any notes, it is assumed the trait was scored on the upper (adaxial) leaf surface.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Variable describing whether mature (fully expanded) adult phase leaves on adult plants have hairs (trichomes).
A leaf pubescence trait [TO:0002722] which is the presence or absence of trichomes [PO:0006504] (hairs) on the leaf lamina [PO:0020039] of a fully expanded adult phase leaf [PO:0006340].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Variable describing whether mature (fully expanded) adult phase leaves on adult plants have hairs (trichomes).

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf emergences (pubescence, pruinescence, hairs, spines, thorns) [TRY:677] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait captures the presence or absence of hairs on mature (fully expanded), adult phase leaves on adult plants. Best practice is to sample leaves that are recently fully expanded, since older leaves have often shed many of their hairs. The accompanying methods should specify if the trait was scored on the upper (adaxial) or lower (abaxial) surface of the leaf; in the absence of any notes, it is assumed the trait was scored on the upper (adaxial) leaf surface.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Variable describing whether fully expanded juvenile phase leaves (on adult or juvenile plants) have hairs (trichomes).

A leaf pubescence trait [TO:0002722] which is the presence or absence of trichomes [PO:0006504] (hairs) on the leaf lamina [PO:0020039] of a juvenile vascular leaf [PO:0006339] (on adult or juvenile plants).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Variable describing whether fully expanded juvenile phase leaves (on adult or juvenile plants) have hairs (trichomes).

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf emergences (pubescence, pruinescence, hairs, spines, thorns) [TRY:677] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait captures the presence or absence of hairs on fully-expanded juvenile phase leaves. It is best practice for the methods to specify whether these leaves were sampled from adult or juvenile plants. The accompanying methods should also specify if the trait was scored on the upper (adaxial) or lower (abaxial) surface of the leaf; in the absence of any notes, it is assumed the trait was scored on the upper (adaxial) leaf surface.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Variable describing whether immature (still expanding) adult phase leaves on adult plants have hairs (trichomes).

A leaf pubescence trait [TO:0002722] which is the presence or absence of trichomes [PO:0006504] (hairs) on the leaf lamina [PO:0020039] of an adult phase leaf [PO:0006340] still in the vascular leaf expansion stage [PO:0001052].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Variable describing whether immature (still expanding) adult phase leaves on adult plants have hairs (trichomes).

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf emergences (pubescence, pruinescence, hairs, spines, thorns) [TRY:677] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait captures the presence or absence of hairs on immature (still expanding) leaves on adult plants. The accompanying methods should specify if the trait was scored on the upper (adaxial) or lower (abaxial) surface of the leaf; in the absence of any notes, it is assumed the trait was scored on the upper (adaxial) leaf surface.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Human visible dominant colour of the surface of a leaf.
A leaf morphology trait [TO:0000748] which is which is the dominant (primary [NCIT:C25251]) colour [PATO:0000014] of the leaf lamina [PO:0020039].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Human visible dominant colour of the surface of a leaf.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Leaf color [TRY:582]  (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Surface reflectivity of a leaf, indicating whether the leaf lamina is shiny or dull.
A leaf morphology trait [TO:0000748] which is the reflectivity [PATO:0001297] of the surface [NCIT:C25245] of a mature [PATO:0001701]  leaf lamina [PO:0020039].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Surface reflectivity of a leaf, indicating whether the leaf lamina is shiny or dull.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: There will be overlap between this trait and the trait `leaf_glaucousness`. This trait can be used to document surface reflectivity more broadly, not only distinguishing between leaf lamina that are glaucous versus not glaucous.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Leaf arrangement at a stem node, indicating the relative number and position of leaves at a single stem note.

A leaf [PO:0025034] spatial pattern [PATO:0000060] trait which is the phyllotaxy [TO:0006014] of leaves, indicating a leaf's position [TO:0000541] relative to other leaves at a stem node [PO:0020141].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Leaf arrangement at a stem node, indicating the relative number and position of leaves at a single stem note.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf_arrangement [GIFT:4.15.1] (https://gift.uni-goettingen.de)
close match: Leaf distribution along the shoot axis (arrangement type) [TRY:16] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait only includes true phyllotaxis, the arrangement of leaves at a single node, while the trait `leaf arrangement` indicates how the leaves are presented along the entire shoot system. See the trait `stem_growth_habit` for whole-plant leaf pattern terms, such as `rosette`.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Leaf arrangement across stem nodes, indicating the 3-dimensional arrangement of leaves along the length of the stem.

A leaf [PO:0025034] spatial pattern [PATO:0000060] trait which is the position [TO:0000541] and arrangement [NCIT:C61532] of leaves between stem nodes [PO:0020141], indicating how leaves align and cluster along the vegetative shoot system [PO:0025607].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Leaf arrangement across stem nodes, indicating the 3-dimensional arrangement of leaves along the length of the stem.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf_arrangement [GIFT:4.15.1] (https://gift.uni-goettingen.de)
close match: Leaf distribution along the shoot axis (arrangement type) [TRY:16] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Leaf arrangement, as defined for this trait, indicates patterns of leaf arrangement across nodes, including both formal terms (decussate, distichous, spiral) as well as indications of leaf clustering due to variation in internode length. See the trait `leaf phyllotaxis` for terms describing leaf arrangement at a single node. See the trait `stem_growth_habit` for whole-plant leaf pattern terms, such as `rosette`.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The angle between a shoot and a leaf that connects to the shoot axis.
A leaf position trait [TO:0000541] which is the angle [PATO:0002326] of a leaf axil [PO:0009023], the space between a leaf [PO:0025034] and the stem [PO:0009047] to which it is attached.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The angle between a shoot and a leaf that connects to the shoot axis.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: related match: Leaf angle (inclination, orientation) [TRY:3] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait records the angle between the upper surface of a leaf and the stem to which it is attached. The slope of the leaf lamina relative to the solar zenith is a separate trait, `leaf_inclination_angle`.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The inclination angle of the upper (adaxial) leaf lamina surface relative to a horizontal plane, such that a leaf surface facing the solar zenith has an angle of 0.

A leaf position trait [TO:0000541] which is the inclination angle [PATO:0002326] of the adaxial [PATO:0002047] leaf lamina [PO:0020039] surface relative to a horizontal [PATO:0001855] plane, such that an adaxial leaf surface facing the solar zenith [ECSO:00002723] has an angle of 0.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The inclination angle of the upper (adaxial) leaf lamina surface relative to a horizontal plane, such that a leaf surface facing the solar zenith has an angle of 0.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Leaf angle (inclination, orientation) [TRY:3] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait records the slope of the leaf lamina relative to the ground surface. The angle between a stem and the leaf lamina is a separate trait, `leaf_axil_angle`. Complanate leaves can be scored as having a `leaf_inclination_angle` of 0.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Binary variable describing whether leaves are pendulous, hanging loosely downward and possessing the ability to flutter.
A leaf position trait [TO:0000541] which indicates whether leaves [PO:0025034] are pendulous [APD:glossary/40066], hanging loosely downward and possessing the ability to flutter.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Binary variable describing whether leaves are pendulous, hanging loosely downward and possessing the ability to flutter.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf angle (inclination, orientation) [TRY:3] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This is a binary categorical trait, scoring whether leaves are pendulous and therefore hanging loosely downward and able to flutter. Two additional traits, `leaf_inclination_angle` and `leaf_axil_angle` document the actual angle of the leaf lamina relative to, respectively, the solar zenith and the stem.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Thickness of the cuticle on the lower leaf surface.
A portion of plant tissue morphology trait [TO:0000843] which is the thickness [PATO:0000915] of cuticle [PO:0000022] on the abaxial [PATO:0002046] (lower) leaf lamina [PO:0020039].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Thickness of the cuticle on the lower leaf surface.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf cuticula thickness [TRY:716] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Cuticle thickness on the lower leaf surface

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Thickness of the cuticle on the upper leaf surface.
A portion of plant tissue morphology trait [TO:0000843] which is the thickness [PATO:0000915] of cuticle [PO:0000022] on the adaxial [PATO:0002047] (upper) leaf lamina [PO:0020039].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Thickness of the cuticle on the upper leaf surface.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf cuticula thickness [TRY:716] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Cuticle thickness on the upper leaf surface

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Thickness of the epidermis, where the leaf lamina side is not specified.

A portion of plant tissue morphology trait [TO:0000843] which is the thickness [PATO:0000915] of epidermis [PO:0005679] tissue [CARO:0000043] , in samples where the leaf lamina [PO:0020039] side (abaxial [PATO:0002046] versus adaxial [PATO:0002047]) is not specified.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Thickness of the epidermis, where the leaf lamina side is not specified.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Leaf epidermis thickness [TRY:101] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Thickness of the epidermis on the lower side of the leaf.

A portion of plant tissue morphology trait [TO:0000843] which is the thickness [PATO:0000915] of epidermis [PO:0005679] tissue [CARO:0000043] on the abaxial [PATO:0002046] (lower) side of the leaf lamina [PO:0020039].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Thickness of the epidermis on the lower side of the leaf.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf epidermis thickness [TRY:101] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Thickness of the epidermis on the upper side of the leaf.

A portion of plant tissue morphology trait [TO:0000843] which is the thickness [PATO:0000915] of epidermis [PO:0005679] tissue [CARO:0000043] on the adaxial [PATO:0002047] (upper) side of the leaf lamina [PO:0020039].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Thickness of the epidermis on the upper side of the leaf.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf epidermis thickness [TRY:101] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Epidermal cell density averaged across the upper and lower sides of the leaf.

A plant cell morphology trait [TO:0002683] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the count [NCIT:C25463] of epidermal cells [PO:0004013] to leaf lamina [PO:0020039] area [PATO_0001323], averaged across the abaxial [PATO:0002046] (lower) and adaxial [PATO:0002047] (upper) sides of the leaf lamina.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Epidermal cell density averaged across the upper and lower sides of the leaf.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Epidermal cell density on the lower side of the leaf.

A plant cell morphology trait [TO:0002683] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the count [NCIT:C25463] of epidermal cells [PO:0004013] on the abaxial [PATO:0002046] (lower) side of the leaf lamina [PO:0020039] to leaf lamina area [PATO_0001323].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Epidermal cell density on the lower side of the leaf.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Lower leaf side epidermal cell density

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Epidermal cell density on the upper side of the leaf.

A plant cell morphology trait [TO:0002683] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the count [NCIT:C25463] of epidermal cells [PO:0004013] on the adaxial [PATO:0002047] (upper) side of the leaf lamina [PO:0020039] to leaf lamina area [PATO_0001323].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Epidermal cell density on the upper side of the leaf.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Upper leaf side epidermal cell density

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Thickness of the hypodermis on the lower side of the leaf.

A portion of plant tissue morphology trait [TO:0000843] which is the thickness [PATO:0000915] of hypodermis [PO:0005051] tissue [CARO:0000043] on the abaxial [PATO:0002046] (lower) side of the leaf lamina [PO:0020039].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Thickness of the hypodermis on the lower side of the leaf.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf hypodermis thickness [TRY:806] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Thickness of the hypodermis on the upper side of the leaf.

A portion of plant tissue morphology trait [TO:0000843] which is the thickness [PATO:0000915] of hypodermis [PO:0005051] tissue [CARO:0000043] on the adaxial [PATO:0002047] (upper) side of the leaf lamina [PO:0020039].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Thickness of the hypodermis on the upper side of the leaf.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf hypodermis thickness [TRY:806] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Thickness of palisade mesophyll tissue on the lower side of the leaf.

A portion of plant tissue morphology trait [TO:0000843] which is the thickness [PATO:0000915] of palisade mesophyll [PO:0005648] tissue [CARO:0000043] on the abaxial [PATO:0002046] (lower) side of the leaf lamina [PO:0020039].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Thickness of palisade mesophyll tissue on the lower side of the leaf.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Thickness of palisade mesophyll tissue on the upper side of the leaf.

A portion of plant tissue morphology trait [TO:0000843] which is the thickness [PATO:0000915] of palisade mesophyll [PO:0005648] tissue [CARO:0000043] on the adaxial [PATO:0002047] (upper) side of the leaf lamina [PO:0020039].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Thickness of palisade mesophyll tissue on the upper side of the leaf.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Length of individual leaf palisade cells.
A plant cell morphology trait [TO:0002683] which is the length [PATO:0000122] of individual palisade mesophyll cells [PO:0006206].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Length of individual leaf palisade cells.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Width of individual leaf palisade cells.
A plant cell morphology trait [TO:0002683] which is the width [PATO:0000921] of individual palisade mesophyll cells [PO:0006206].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Width of individual leaf palisade cells.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The number of layers of palisade cells in a leaf.
A portion of plant tissue morphology trait [TO:0000843] which is the count [NCIT:C25463] of cell layers [UBERON:0000119] of palisade mesophyll cells [PO:0006206].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The number of layers of palisade cells in a leaf.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Number of layers of palisade cells

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Thickness of spongy mesophyll tissue in a leaf.
A portion of plant tissue morphology trait [TO:0000843] which is the thickness [PATO:0000915] of spongy mesophyll [PO:0005647] tissue [CARO:0000043] within the leaf lamina [PO:0020039].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Thickness of spongy mesophyll tissue in a leaf.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Leaf mesophyll spongiophyll thickness [TRY:805] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Cell cross-sectional area.
A plant cell size [TO:0002684] trait which is the cross-sectional [NCIT:C63795] area [PATO:0001323] of a cell [CL:0000000].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Cell cross-sectional area.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Leaf mesophyll cell area [TRY:573] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
close match: Leaf epidermis cell area [TRY:338] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait can be used to map the area of cell types that are not already explicitly listed as their own trait. The cell type and tissue/organ being measured needs to be specified under `measurement_remarks` or as a `method_context`.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Density of stomata on the lower leaf surface.

A leaf stomatal complex frequency trait [TO:0000566] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the count [NCIT:C25463] of stomata [PO:0008032] on the abaxial [PATO:0002046] (lower) leaf lamina [PO:0020039] to the leaf lamina area [PATO:0001323].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Density of stomata on the lower leaf surface.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Stomata density [TRY:63] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
exact match: Stomata density abaxial [TOP371] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Stomatal density on the lower leaf surface

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Density of stomata on the upper leaf surface.

A leaf stomatal complex frequency trait [TO:0000566] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the count [NCIT:C25463] of stomata [PO:0008032] on the adaxial [PATO:0002047] (upper) leaf lamina [PO:0020039] to the leaf lamina area [PATO:0001323].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Density of stomata on the upper leaf surface.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Stomata density [TRY:63] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
exact match: Stomata density adaxial [TOP372] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Stomatal density on the upper leaf surface

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Density of stomata averaged across both leaf surfaces.

A leaf stomatal complex frequency trait [TO:0000566] which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the count [NCIT:C25463] of stomata [PO:0008032] to  leaf lamina [PO:0020039] area [PATO:0001323], averaged the across the abaxial [PATO:0002046] and adaxial [PATO:0002047] sides of the leaf lamina.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Density of stomata averaged across both leaf surfaces.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Stomata density [TRY:63] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
exact match: Stomata density trait [TOP370] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Stomatal density averaged across both leaf surfaces

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Distribution of stomatal across the two leaf surfaces.
A leaf stomatal complex frequency trait [TO:0000566] which indicates whether stomata [PO:0008032] occur on the abaxial [PATO:0002046] and/or adaxial [PATO:0002047] leaf lamina [PO:0020039].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Distribution of stomatal across the two leaf surfaces.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Stomata distribution to ab- and adaxial leaf surfaces [TRY:781] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Variable indicating if stomata are covered by hairs and, if hairy, the density of hairs present.
A leaf stomatal complex frequency trait [TO:0000566] which is the pilosity [PATO:0000066] (hairiness) of the stomatal pores [PO:0008032].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Variable indicating if stomata are covered by hairs and, if hairy, the density of hairs present.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Length of guard cells.
A leaf stomatal complex frequency trait [TO:0000566] which indicates the length [PATO:0000122] of a guard cell [PO:0000293].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Length of guard cells.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Stomata guard cell size [TRY:733] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Proportion of incoming visible light (between 400-700 nm) that is transmitted through a leaf.

A leaf [PO:0025034] optical [NCIT:C16940] properties trait which is the proportion [PATO:0001470] of incoming visible light [NCIT:C17732] that is transmitted [SWEET:procWave/Transmission] through a leaf.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Proportion of incoming visible light (between 400-700 nm) that is transmitted through a leaf.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Leaf light transmittance [TRY:535] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Proportion of incoming visible light (between 400-700 nm) that is absorbed by a leaf.
A leaf [PO:0025034] optical [NCIT:C16940] properties trait which is the proportion [PATO:0001470] of incoming visible light [NCIT:C17732] that is absorbed [SWEET:procWave/Absorption] by a leaf.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Proportion of incoming visible light (between 400-700 nm) that is absorbed by a leaf.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Leaf light absorption (extinction) [TRY:10] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Proportion of incoming visible light (between 400-700 nm) that is reflected by a leaf.
A leaf [PO:0025034] optical [NCIT:C16940] properties trait which is the proportion [PATO:0001470] of incoming  visible light [NCIT:C17732] that is reflected [SWEET:procWave/Reflection] by a leaf.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Proportion of incoming visible light (between 400-700 nm) that is reflected by a leaf.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Proportion of incoming near infra-red light (between 750-10500 nm) that is reflected by a leaf.

A leaf [PO:0025034] optical [NCIT:C16940] properties trait which is the proportion [PATO:0001470] of incoming infrared radiation [ENVO:21001214] that is reflected [SWEET:procWave/Reflection] by a leaf.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Proportion of incoming near infra-red light (between 750-10500 nm) that is reflected by a leaf.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Cross-sectional area of a stem, including both wood and bark.
A stem morphology trait [TO:0000361] which is the cross-sectional [NCIT:C63795] area [PATO:0001323] of a stem [PO:0009047] segment which includes the bark [PO:0004518].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Cross-sectional area of a stem, including both wood and bark.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This is not a trait itself, since it is dependent on the location sampled. However, values might be reported that are effectively contexts for another trait, such as bark thickness or Huber value.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Cross-sectional area of a stem without bark.

A stem morphology trait [TO:0000361] which is the cross-sectional [NCIT:C63795] area [PATO:0001323] of a stem [PO:0009047] segment from which the bark [PO:0004518] has been removed; this includes both sapwood [PO:0004513] and, if present heartwood [PO:0004512].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Cross-sectional area of a stem without bark.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This is not a trait itself, since it is dependent on the location sampled. However, values might be reported that are effectively contexts for another trait, such as bark thickness or Huber value. Although it is defined as the diameter of the entire stem without bark, it is generally measured on narrow branches that have not yet developed heartwood and therefore is the cross-section of sapwood.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Cross-sectional area of the terminal twig, measured just beyond the final branching node.
A stem morphology trait [TO:0000361] which is the cross-sectional [NCIT:C63795] area [PATO:0001323] of the most distal [PATO:0001234] branch [PO:0025073].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Cross-sectional area of the terminal twig, measured just beyond the final branching node.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Root biomass depth distribution coefficient ('B' from Gale & Grigal 1987), where high values indicate that root biomass is allocated deeper in the soil. To calculate the model parameter, the required input is a plot of the cumulative root distribution from the surface, where [Y] is the cumulative fraction of roots from the surface to a depth [d]. An asymptotic nonlinear model is used to describe the vertical root distribution: Y = 1 - b^d where Y is the cumulative root fraction from the surface to soil depth d in centimeters and b the estimated parameter.

A root system morphology trait [TO:0000985] which is a model parameter [STATO:0000034] indicating the distribution [PATO:0000060] of a plant's roots [PO:0009005] with depth [PATO:0001595]. To calculate the model parameter, the required input is a plot of the cumulative root distribution from the surface, where [Y] is the cumulative fraction of roots from the surface to a depth [d]. An asymptotic nonlinear model is used to describe the vertical root distribution: Y = 1 - b^d where Y is the cumulative root fraction from the surface to soil depth d in centimeters and b the estimated parameter.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Root biomass depth distribution coefficient ('B' from Gale & Grigal 1987), where high values indicate that root biomass is allocated deeper in the soil. To calculate the model parameter, the required input is a plot of the cumulative root distribution from the surface, where [Y] is the cumulative fraction of roots from the surface to a depth [d]. An asymptotic nonlinear model is used to describe the vertical root distribution: Y = 1 - b^d where Y is the cumulative root fraction from the surface to soil depth d in centimeters and b the estimated parameter.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The fraction of total reproductive investment required to mature a seed that is invested in non-seed tissues. It is calculated as one minus, the ratio of total biomass investment in seeds to total biomass investment in all reproductive tissues, including flower buds, flowers, fruits, dispersal tissues, aborted seeds, and successfully matured seeds.

A reproductive shoot system [PO:0025082] biomass allocation [EnvThes:21360] trait which is one minus the ratio [PATO:0001470] of total plant seed [PO:0009010] dry [PATO:0001824] mass [PATO:0000125] to total plant reproductive shoot system tissue dry mass where reproductive tissues include all flower buds [PO:0000056], flowers [PO:0009046], fruits [PO:0009001], dispersal [EnvThes:21038] tissues, and seeds produced during the developmental process involved in reproduction [GO:0003006].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The fraction of total reproductive investment required to mature a seed that is invested in non-seed tissues. It is calculated as one minus, the ratio of total biomass investment in seeds to total biomass investment in all reproductive tissues, including flower buds, flowers, fruits, dispersal tissues, aborted seeds, and successfully matured seeds.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The mass of seed accessory costs, which is the total biomass investment in all reproductive tissues, excluding biomass invested in successfully matured seeds; it includes all biomass invested in flower buds, flowers, fruits, dispersal tissues and aborted seeds.

A reproductive shoot system [PO:0025082] biomass allocation [EnvThes:21360] trait which is the sum of the dry [PATO:0001824] mass [PATO:0000125] of all flower buds [PO:0000055], flowers [PO:0009046], fruits [PO:0009001], aborted seeds, and dispersal [EnvThes:21038] tissues produced during the developmental process involved in reproduction [GO:0003006], but excludes mature [PATO:0001701] seed [PO:0009010] dry mass.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The mass of seed accessory costs, which is the total biomass investment in all reproductive tissues, excluding biomass invested in successfully matured seeds; it includes all biomass invested in flower buds, flowers, fruits, dispersal tissues and aborted seeds.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Linear dimension from the base to the apex of a bud, even if this is not the longest dimension.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Linear dimension from the base to the apex of a bud, even if this is not the longest dimension.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The number of stamens or stamen bundles (fascicles) in one whorl, considering both fertile stamens and staminodes.

An androecium morphology trait [TO:0000994] which is the total count [NCIT:C25463] of stamens [PO:0009029], staminodes [PO:0009077] or stamen bundles (fascicles [NCIT:C79692]) in each floral whorl [PO:0025023].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The number of stamens or stamen bundles (fascicles) in one whorl, considering both fertile stamens and staminodes.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This character is not applicable for spiral or irregular stamen arrangements, nor when there is a single structural stamen (i.e., one stamen, no staminodes; e.g., Chloranthus, Chloranthaceae). Definition derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '332. Androecium structural merism (C1)'

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Number of androecium parts in each whorl (Androecium structural merism)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Structural phyllotaxy of the androecium, considering both fertile stamens and staminodes. In cases of stamen fascicles, it is the phyllotaxis of fascicles, not individual stamens that are recorded.

An androecium morphology trait [TO:0000994] which is the spatial pattern or distribution [PATO:0000060] (phyllotaxy [TO:0006014]) of stamen [PO:0009029], staminodes [PO:0009077] or stamen bundles (fascicles [NCIT:C79692]) in each floral whorl [PO:0025023].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This character is not applicable when there is a single structural stamen (i.e., one stamen, no staminodes; e.g., Chloranthus, Chloranthaceae). Definition and trait values derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '330. Androecium structural phyllotaxy (D1)'

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The number of whorls, considering both fertile stamens and staminodes. In cases of stamen fascicles, the count of whorls of fascicles is recorded.

An androecium morphology trait [TO:0000994] which is the total count [NCIT:C25463] of whorls [PO:0025023] comprising the androecium [PO:0009061], considering both stamen [PO:0009029] and staminodes [PO:0009077]. If stamens are grouped into fascicles [NCIT:C79692], the trait is the count of whorls of fascicles.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The number of whorls, considering both fertile stamens and staminodes. In cases of stamen fascicles, the count of whorls of fascicles is recorded.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This character is not applicable for spiral or irregular stamen arrangements, or when there is a single structural stamen (i.e., one stamen, no staminodes; e.g., Chloranthus, Chloranthaceae). Definition derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '331. Number of androecium structural whorls (C1)'

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Anther attachment refers to the area of insertion of the filament on the anther connective (i.e. the tissue connecting the two thecae of an anther).

An androecium morphology trait [TO:0000994] which indicates how the filament [PO:0009067] is attached to [PATO:0001667] the tissue [CARO:0000043] connecting the two thecae [PO:0009069] (pollen [PO:0025281] sacs) of the anthers [PO:0009066], affecting the spatial pattern [PATO:0000060] of the stamens [PO:0009029].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Anther attachment refers to the area of insertion of the filament on the anther connective (i.e. the tissue connecting the two thecae of an anther).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Definition and trait values derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '312. Anther attachment (D1)'

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Apical (distal) connective extensions (also called 'distal connective protrusions') are sterile anther structures that distally extend beyond the level of the thecae (i.e., the two lateral pairs of pollen sacs of a tetrasporangiate anther).

An androecium morphology trait [TO:0000994] which is whether anthers [PO:0009066] have protrusions [NCIT:C50710] that extend above the two theca [PO:0009069] (pollen [PO:0025281] sacs), and, if present, the shape [PATO:0000052] and the relative length [PATO:0000122] of the protrusion relative to the length of the entire anther.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Apical (distal) connective extensions (also called 'distal connective protrusions') are sterile anther structures that distally extend beyond the level of the thecae (i.e., the two lateral pairs of pollen sacs of a tetrasporangiate anther).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait records both absence or presence of anther connective extensions and also the shape of these extensions in terms of length in relation to the length of the thecae. http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Anther dehiscence refers to the type of opening of the anther when releasing its pollen through the stomia.

An androecium morphology trait [TO:0000994] which is the length [PATO:0000122] and shape [PATO:0000052] of the stomia [PO:0020101] that form the anther dehiscence zone [PO:0005011]; stomia are the usually slit-like [PATO:0002482] openings in the anther [PO:0009066] through which pollen [PO:0025281] is released.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Orientation of anther at anthesis.

An androecium morphology trait [TO:0000994] which is the position [PATO:0000140] and orientation [PATO:0000133] of the stomia [PO:0020101] that form the anther dehiscence zone [PO:0005011]; stomia are the slit-like [PATO:0002482] openings in the anther [PO:0009066] through which pollen [PO:0025281] is released.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Orientation of anther at anthesis.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Anthers of angiosperms are rather uniform in their basic structure. They normally have four microsporangia (pollen sacs) that are arranged pair-wise in two thecae. The two microsporangia of a theca usually release their pollen grains through a common opening (stomium). Often, it is difficult to establish anther orientation clearly in a flower as this is a gradual feature with many intermediate stages. Definition and trait values derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '311. Anther orientation (D1)'

A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the count [NCIT:C25463] of fertile [PATO:0000955] stamens [PO:0009029] on a hermaphrodite [PATO:0001340] flower [PO:0009046] or male [PATO:0000384] flower.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Trait that considers the absence or presence of the filament, and in the latter case, the shape of the filament. Shape is considered in terms of length and width and is defined in relation to anther length/width.

A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is whether a filament [PO:0009067] is present [PATO:0000467] or absent [PATO:0000462], and if present, the shape [PATO:0000052] and the relative length [PATO:0000122], width [PATO:0000921], and thickness [PATO:0000915] of the filament.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Trait that considers the absence or presence of the filament, and in the latter case, the shape of the filament. Shape is considered in terms of length and width and is defined in relation to anther length/width.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: The width of the filament may thus either be broad as in laminar (e.g., Eupomatiaceae) or bulky stamens (e.g., Chloranthaceae), or narrow (filamentous) as found in many core eudicots groups (e.g., Rosaceae). This trait is considered inapplicable when filaments are entirely fused with each other or to the perianth. Definition and trait values derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '305. Filament (D1)'

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#scop.@value: inapplicable when filaments are entirely fused with each other or to the perianth

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Fusion of stamen (and staminode) filaments among each other at anthesis (congenitally or postgenitally) is recorded on a continuous scale, from 0 (free filaments) to 1 (filaments fused along their entire length).

A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the proportion [PATO:0001470] of the length [PATO:0000122] of the stamen [PO:0009029] (or staminode [PO:0009077]) filaments [PO:0009067] that is fused [NCIT:C124537] together at anthesis [PO:0009068].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Fusion of stamen (and staminode) filaments among each other at anthesis (congenitally or postgenitally) is recorded on a continuous scale, from 0 (free filaments) to 1 (filaments fused along their entire length).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Partial fusion is recorded using an approximate number between these two extremes (e.g., 0.1 corresponds to basal fusion, 0.5 to fusion along half of the length of filaments). Definition derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '306. Fusion of filaments (C1)'

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The fusion of filaments with the innermost perianth organs at anthesis on a continuous scale, from 0 (filaments completely free from perianth) to 1 (filaments fused along their entire length with the perianth; the 'entire length' of the filament is defined as the distance between the floral base and the joint between filament and anther).

A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the proportion [PATO:0001470] of the length [PATO:0000122] of the stamen [PO:0009029] (or staminode [PO:0009077]) filaments [PO:0009067] that are fused [NCIT:C124537] to the innermost perianth [PO:0009058] organ [PO:0009008] at anthesis [PO:0009068].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The fusion of filaments with the innermost perianth organs at anthesis on a continuous scale, from 0 (filaments completely free from perianth) to 1 (filaments fused along their entire length with the perianth; the 'entire length' of the filament is defined as the distance between the floral base and the joint between filament and anther).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Partial fusion is recorded using an approximate number between these two extremes (e.g., 0.1 corresponds to basal fusion, 0.5 to fusion along half of the length of perianth parts). If two (or more) stamen whorls (including staminodial whorls) differ in their extent of filament fusion with the perianth, this trait is recorded as a range of values. For example, if the filaments of an outermost stamen whorl are fused, up to 90% of their length, but an inner whorl only up to 50%, the trait is assigned a range of 0.5 to 0.9. The rationale for this is to provide a general trait that allows comparison of fusion among all angiosperms. Definition derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '308. Fusion of filaments to inner perianth series (C1)'

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Fusion of filaments to inner perianth series

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Structural phyllotaxy of the gynoecium.

A gynoecium [PO:0009062] morphology trait which is either the count [NCIT:C25463] of whorls [PO:0025023] of carpels [PO:0009030] comprising the gynoecium or other descriptors of carpel phyllotaxy [TO:0006014].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Structural phyllotaxy of the gynoecium.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait is not applicable to unicarpellate flowers. Definition and trait values derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '400. Gynoecium phyllotaxy (D1)'

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The different types of placentation in apocarpous/unicarpellate and in syncarpous gynoecia.
A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the position [PATO:0000140] of the ovules [PO:0020003] within the ovary [PO:0009072], known as placentation [APD:glossary/40074].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The different types of placentation in apocarpous/unicarpellate and in syncarpous gynoecia.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: In apocarpous and unicarpellate gynoecia, placentation is often described as marginal as the ovules are usually attached along the ventral slit (i.e., the zone where the carpel margins become postgenitally closed during carpel development). In syncarpous gynoecia there are three main types of placentation, 1) axile placentation refers to ovaries where the ovules are placed in the angle between carpel flanks in the center of the ovary; 2) in ovaries with parietal placentation the ovules attach to the ovary wall where two carpels meet; 3) in ovaries with free-central placentation the ovules are attached to a central column that emerges from the base of the ovary and protrudes into the non-septate ovary. It is not unusual that syncarpous gynoecia show a transition from proximally axile to a distally parietal placentation (e.g., Polemoniaceae). Basal and apical placentation may occur both in apocarpous/unicarpellate and in syncarpous gynoecia. Usually there is one longitudinal series of ovules attached to each carpel margin. However, both in apocarpous/unicarpellate and in syncarpous gynoecia there may be more than one series of ovules at the flanks of a carpel. These latter cases are referred to as laminar (or laminar-diffuse) placentation (e.g., in some Nymphaeaceae). A placenta that is protruding from its surroundings and has more than two series of ovules (either axile or parietal) is called protruding-diffuse. Definition and trait values derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '412. Placentation (D1)'

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Degree of ovary fusion expressed as a fraction of the total length of the ovary (from the floral base to the apex of the ovary).

A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which, for flowers with multiple carpels, is the proportion [PATO:0001470] of the length [PATO:0000122] of the ovaries [PO:0009072] that are fused [NCIT:C124537] together.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Degree of ovary fusion expressed as a fraction of the total length of the ovary (from the floral base to the apex of the ovary).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Fusion of styles and stigmas is not taken into account for this trait. Not applicable when there is a single carpel. Definition derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '403. Fusion of ovaries (C1)'

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#scop.@value: Not applicable when there is a single carpel.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The position of the flower ovary relative to the insertion level of the remaining floral organs.

A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the position [PATO:0000140] of the plant ovary [PO:0009072] relative to the other flower [PO:0009046] organs [PO:0009008], in particular whether the ovary is attached above or below the perianth [PO:0009058] organs (the petals [PO:0009032] and sepals [PO:0009031]).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The position of the flower ovary relative to the insertion level of the remaining floral organs.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: The ovary is the part of the gynoecium where the ovules are produced. The ovary may be located on the receptacle and thus be positioned above the insertion level of the remaining floral organs (i.e., the ovary is superior and the flower is hypogynous). Alternatively, the ovary may be embedded in the receptacle and therefore be located below the insertion level of the remaining floral organs (i.e., the ovary is inferior and the flower is epigynous). Flowers with a hypanthium may either have a superior ovary (perigyny; e.g., many Rosaceae) or an inferior ovary (epiperigyny). It is also possible that the ovary is inferior to a certain degree only, such as half-inferior, if the receptacle is surrounding the ovary to its mid-level. Definition and trait values derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '102. Ovary position (D1)'

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Number of ovules per carpel recorded as a continuous character (with integer values of 1 and above).
A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the count [NCIT:C25463] of ovules [PO:0020003] per fertile [PATO:0000955] carpel [PO:0009030].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Number of ovules per carpel recorded as a continuous character (with integer values of 1 and above).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Reduced (sterile) carpels are not taken into account here. Definition derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '411. Number of ovules per functional carpel (C1)'

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Number of ovules per functional carpel

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The ways in which perianth organs may look different from each other in a given flower.

A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which indicates whether petals [PO:0009032] and sepals [PO:0009031] are differentiated or identical and the various ways they can be identical or different.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The ways in which perianth organs may look different from each other in a given flower.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Typically, outer perianth parts are sepaloid and protect the other floral organs during floral development, while inner organs are often petaloid and play a role in pollinator attraction (Endress, 1994). However, it is also possible that all parts are either sepaloid or petaloid but remain differentiated in shape, size, and/or texture. In case of spiral perianths, differentiation may be continuous (i.e., gradual), whereby two successively initiated organs are very similar or only slightly different, while the outermost and innermost organs at both ends of the spiral are very different from each other (e.g., Chimonanthus). In the special case of perianths consisting of a single whorl, they are scored as undifferentiated. This perianth differentiation trait may be seen as both functional (the parting vs. sharing of functions among perianth parts) and developmental (the expression of a genetic program for different forms of perianth parts vs. a single program for a single type of perianth part morphology). Within-whorl differentiation, whereby organs of the same whorl take different forms, is common in zygomorphic flowers (e.g., Balsaminaceae, Fabaceae, Orchidaceae) but is not taken into account with this trait. This trait is not applicable when the perianth is absent. Definition and trait values derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '234. Perianth differentiation (D1)'

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#scop.@value: Not applicable when the perianth is absent

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Fusion of perianth organs (congenital or postgenital) at anthesis, recorded on a continuous scale, from 0 (free parts) to 1 (parts fused along their entire length).

A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the proportion [PATO:0001470] of the length [PATO:0000122] of perianth [PO:0009058] parts (sepals [PO:0009031], petals [PO:0009032], and tepals [PO:0009033]) that are fused [NCIT:C124537] together at anthesis [PO:0009068].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Fusion of perianth organs (congenital or postgenital) at anthesis, recorded on a continuous scale, from 0 (free parts) to 1 (parts fused along their entire length).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Partial fusion was recorded using an approximate number between these two extremes (e.g., 0.1 corresponds to basal fusion, 0.5 to fusion along half of the length of perianth parts). In case of multiple whorls, this trait records within-whorl fusion. For example, if organs within each whorl are fused along their entire length, a trait value of 1 is recorded. In cases where organs of two whorls are fused into a common tubular structure, such as frequently observed in monocots (e.g., Polygonatum), the perianth is considered to be fused. If the two (or more) whorls differed in their extent of fusion, a range of trait values may be recorded. For example, if the calyx is only basally fused, up to 10% of its length, but the corolla is entirely fused, a range of 0.1 to 1 is recorded as the trait value for the species. Definition derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '204. Fusion of perianth (C1)'

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The number of perianth parts in each whorl, recorded as a continuous trait (with integer values of 1 and above).

A perianth morphology trait [TO:0000275] which is the count [NCIT:C25463] of perianth [PO:0009058] parts (sepals [PO:0009031], petals [PO:0009032], and tepals [PO:0009033]) in each floral whorl [PO:0025023].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The number of perianth parts in each whorl, recorded as a continuous trait (with integer values of 1 and above).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Not applicable when perianth phyllotaxis is spiral or irregular or when the perianth is absent. Definition derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '232. Perianth merism (C1)'

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Number of perianth parts in each whorl (Perianth merism)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#scop.@value: Not applicable when perianth phyllotaxis is spiral or irregular or when the perianth is absent.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The total number of perianth parts, including sepals, petals, or any form of tepal.
A perianth morphology trait [TO:0000275] which is the total count [NCIT:C25463] of perianth [PO:0009058] parts, including sepals [PO:0009031], petals [PO:0009032], and any form of tepal [PO:0009033].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The total number of perianth parts, including sepals, petals, or any form of tepal.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: A value of zero was scored when the perianth is absent. In flowers with perianth whorls fused along their complete length (e.g., Convolvulus), perianth parts are counted based on merism (e.g., if a calyx has 5 distinct sepals and the corolla is entirely fused, then the corolla is often interpreted to consist of five fused petals), anatomy (e.g., number of vascular traces), development (e.g., number of primordia), or comparison with closely related taxa. Definition derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '201. Number of perianth parts (C1)'

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Perianth phyllotaxis at anthesis.

A perianth morphology trait [TO:0000275] which is the phyllotaxy [TO:0006014] of the perianth [PO:0009058] parts (petals [PO:0009032], sepals [PO:0009031], and  tepals [PO:0009033]), at anthesis [PO:0009068]

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Perianth phyllotaxis at anthesis.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Perianth parts may be organised in one or more whorls or along a continuous spiral, usually with wide divergence angles more or less equal to 137.5 degrees. Less frequently, perianth phyllotaxis may be irregular. Perianth phyllotaxis at anthesis may differ from phyllotaxis of perianth part primordia at their inception and it is not uncommon that spirally initiated perianths become whorled later through development. Definition and trait values derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '230. Perianth phyllotaxy (D1)', with more information of differentiating between trait values in this manuscript.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Trait capturing the symmetry of the perianth.

A perianth morphology trait [TO:0000275] which is the symmetry [PATO:0000965] of the perianth [PO:0009058] (petals [PO:0009032], sepals [PO:0009031], and  tepals [PO:0009033]), whereby a perianth is only considered actinomorphic [PATO:0001328] if all perianth whorls [PO:0025023] are actinomorphic.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Trait capturing the symmetry of the perianth.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait is applied to the perianth as a whole. In case of flowers with two or more perianth whorls, species are considered actinomorphic if all whorls are actinomorphic and as zygomorphic if one or more whorls are zygomorphic. Trait is not applicable when the perianth is missing. Definition and trait values derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '207. Symmetry of perianth (D1)'

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#scop.@value: Not applicable when the perianth is missing

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The number of perianth whorls as a continuous trait (with integer values of 1 and above).

A perianth morphology trait [TO:0000275] which is the count [NCIT:C25463] of floral whorls [PO:0025023] that comprise the perianth [PO:0009058] (petals [PO:0009032], sepals [PO:0009031], and  tepals [PO:0009033]).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The number of perianth whorls as a continuous trait (with integer values of 1 and above).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Not applicable when perianth phyllotaxis is spiral or irregular or when the perianth is absent. Definition derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '231. Number of perianth whorls (C1)'

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#scop.@value: Not applicable when perianth phyllotaxis is spiral or irregular or when the perianth is absent.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Pollen grains are often described according to the shape, structure, and position of their apertures. This trait describes the main shape of the many described aperture types.
A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the shape [PATO:0000052], structure [PATO:0000141], and position [PATO:0000140] of the pollen grain [PO:0025281] apertures [GO:0062074].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Pollen grains are often described according to the shape, structure, and position of their apertures. This trait describes the main shape of the many described aperture types.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Aperture terminology is partly determined by the position of the aperture on the pollen grain (either at the pole or at the equator) and pollen grain polarity, in turn, is determined by the spatial orientation of the microspore in the meiotic tetrad. Definition and trait values derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '5002. Aperture shape (D1)''

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The number of apertures per pollen grain as a continuous character.
A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the count [NCIT:C25463] of pollen apertures [GO:0062074] per pollen [PO:0025281] grain.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The number of apertures per pollen grain as a continuous character.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: A pollen aperture is a structurally delimited region of the pollen grain wall through which the pollen tube emerges during pollen germination and which plays a role in harmomegathy. A value of zero is scored when pollen is inaperturate (i.e. when there is no distinct aperture). Aperturate pollen is scored with integer values of 1 and above. Definition derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '5000. Number of apertures (C1)'

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The largest dimension of the pollen grain.
A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the length [PATO:0000122] of a pollen [PO:0025281] grain.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The largest dimension of the pollen grain.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Palynologists typically describe pollen dimensions (and shape) using two measures, the polar axis (P) and the total breadth or diameter of the equatorial axis. Here we use P or E or another measure, whichever is the longest.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Number of fertile or sterile carpels in bisexual or female flowers, recorded as a continuous character (with integer values of 1 and above).

A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the count [NCIT:C25463] of both fertile [PATO:0000955] and female sterile [PATO:0000892] carpels [PO:0009030] in a hermaphrodite [PATO:0001340] flower [PO:0009046] or female [PATO:0000383] flower.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Number of fertile or sterile carpels in bisexual or female flowers, recorded as a continuous character (with integer values of 1 and above).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Includes the number of co-occurring carpellodes (sterile carpels) because this number is often more easily obtained from the literature than the actual number of fertile carpels. However, the number of carpellodes in male flowers is ignored for this character. In multicarpellate, unilocular gynoecia with complete carpel fusion up to the stigma (e.g., Primula), it may be difficult to assess the number of carpels unequivocally. In such cases, the number of carpels is scored only if it is well established based on atomical or developmental investigations. Similarly, in gynoecia where one or more carpels are reduced (e.g., in the pseudomonomerous gynoecia of some Arecaceae, Stauffer et al., 2002), the total number of structural carpels is only scored when unequivocally determined in the literature. Definition derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '401. Number of structural carpels (C1)'

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Trait that captures floral sex, distinguishing among three states, bisexual, incompletely unisexual, and unisexual.

A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the phenotypic sex [PATO:0001894] of a flower [PO:0009046], indicating whether individual flowers have both male [PATO:0000384] and female [PATO:0000383] reproductive structures [UBERON:0005156] (bisexual) or only one type of reproductive organ (unisexual).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Trait that captures floral sex, distinguishing among three states, bisexual, incompletely unisexual, and unisexual.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Defined by Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '100. Floral structural sex (D1)'. See the trait 'sex_type' for plant sex type.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Presence or absence of a style, and, when present, the shape of the style in terms of length and width in relation to ovary length and width.

A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is whether a style [PO:0006469] is present [PATO:0000467] or absent [PATO:0000462], and if present, the shape [PATO:0000052] and the length [PATO:0000122], width [PATO:0000921], and thickness [PATO:0000915] of the style relative to the dimensions of the ovary [PO:0009072].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Presence or absence of a style, and, when present, the shape of the style in terms of length and width in relation to ovary length and width.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait does not distinguish between fused or free styles. Definition and trait values derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '404. Style differentiation (D1)'

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The degree of fusion of styles at anthesis, recorded on a continuous scale, from 0 (free styles) to 1 (styles fused along their entire length, but excluding the stigmatic region).
A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the proportion [PATO:0001470] of the length [PATO:0000122] of styles [PO:0006469] that are fused [NCIT:C124537] together.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The degree of fusion of styles at anthesis, recorded on a continuous scale, from 0 (free styles) to 1 (styles fused along their entire length, but excluding the stigmatic region).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Partial fusion is recorded using an approximate number between these two extremes (e.g., 0.1 corresponds to basal fusion, 0.5 to fusion along half of the total length of the styles). This character is not applicable in unicarpellate flowers. Definition derived from Schoenenberger et al. (2020) for their character '406. Fusion of styles (C1)'

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The length of an individual flower petal.
A floral organ morphology trait [TO:0000862] which is the length [PATO:0000122] of a petal [PO_0009032].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The length of an individual flower petal.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Flower petal length [TRY:3576]  (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Fruit dry mass, including seeds. Fruits will generally be oven-dried.
A fruit morphology trait [TO:0002629] which is the dry [PATO:0001824] mass [PATO:0000125] of a fruit [PO:0009001], including seeds [PO:0009010].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Fruit dry mass, including seeds. Fruits will generally be oven-dried.
