close match: Stem emergences (pubescence, hairs, spines, thorns) [TRY:1256] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
close match: Shoot emergences (pubescence, hairs, spines, thorns) [TRY:1255] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
close match: Leaf emergences (pubescence, pruinescence, hairs, spines, thorns) [TRY:677] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait identifies explicit physical defence structures on a plant. The trait `plant_spinescence` indicates the degree of defence afforded to plants, with values defined by P<U+00C3><U+00A9>rez-Harguindeguy et al. 2013 (doi:10.1071/BT12225).

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Mechanisms plants use to climb, including both specialised leaf and stem adaptations and stem growth habits.

A whole plant [PO:0000003] phenotype [NCIT:C16977] trait that indicates stem [PO:0009047] and leaf [PO:0025034] structures [PATO:0000141] and physical mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] a plant uses to climb [NCIT:C81002] up other plants or substrates.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Mechanisms plants use to climb, including both specialised leaf and stem adaptations and stem growth habits.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: related match: Plant growth form [TRY:42] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Trait indicating whether the leaves or stems of a plant are thick and fleshy because they store water, generally an adaptation to arid or salty environments.

A whole plant [PO:0000003] phenotype [NCIT:C16977] trait that indicates whether any plant tissues [CARO:0000043] are succulent [FLOPO:0900041], indicating they are thick [PATO:0000591] and fleshy [PATO:0002351], generally storing water [CHEBI:15377] as a drought tolerance [TO:0000276] adaptation or filling with water as a salt tolerance [TO:0006001] adaptation.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Trait indicating whether the leaves or stems of a plant are thick and fleshy because they store water, generally an adaptation to arid or salty environments.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: related match: Basic leaf shape [BROT:5] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
exact match: Succulence [GIFT:4.16.1] (https://gift.uni-goettingen.de)
related match: Plant growth form [TRY:42] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Succulence generally has either a water storage function or is a mechanism to cope with (or thrive in) saline conditions. See the categorical trait `plant_tolerance_salt` for plant salt tolerance and salt avoidance strategies and the numeric trait `plant_tolerance_soil_salinity` for the soil salinity a plant can tolerate.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Trait characterising a stem's structure and 3-dimensional extent, including the position of stems, degree of branchiness, density of branches, and branch angles relative to other branches and the ground surface.

A whole plant [PO:0000003] phenotype [NCIT:C16977] trait that indicates the structure [PATO:0000141] and 3-dimensional extent [PATO:0001710] of a plant's vegetative shoot system [PO:0025607], including the position [PATO:0000140] of stems [PO:0009047], degree of branchiness [PATO:0002009], density [PATO:0001019] of branches [PO:0025073], and branch angles [PATO:0002326] relative to each other and the ground surface [sweetontology.net/realmSoil/Ground].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Trait characterising a stem's structure and 3-dimensional extent, including the position of stems, degree of branchiness, density of branches, and branch angles relative to other branches and the ground surface.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: related match: Climber_2 [GIFT:1.4.2] (https://gift.uni-goettingen.de)
exact match: Shoot_orientation [GIFT:1.9.1] (https://gift.uni-goettingen.de)

related match: Shoot growth form [LEDA:3.2] (https://uol.de/en/landeco/research/leda/standards)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait captures how a plant explores 3-dimensional space, with trait values predominantly adjectives that modify the core plant growth forms.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Trait indicating whether a plant retains a leaf canopy throughout the year and what environmental cues are associated with canopy shedding.

A whole plant [PO:0000003] phenotype [NCIT:C16977] trait characterising whether there is a part of the year when a plant sheds all leaves [PO:0025034] (shedability [PATO:0001729]) and the environmental conditions [ENVO:01000203] that cause a plant to shed its leaves.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Trait indicating whether a plant retains a leaf canopy throughout the year and what environmental cues are associated with canopy shedding.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Leaf phenology [BROT:4] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
exact match: whole plant vegetative phenology [BIEN] (https://bien.nceas.ucsb.edu/bien/biendata)

exact match: Phenology [TOP700] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Duration of time that an individual leaf is attached to the stem and physiologically functional; leaf longevity.
The duration [PATO:0001309] that an individual leaf [PO:0025034] is attached to the stem [PO:0009047] and is physiologically functional [PATO:0001510].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Duration of time that an individual leaf is attached to the stem and physiologically functional; leaf longevity.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Average leaf lifespan [BROT:3] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
exact match: leaf life span [BIEN] (https://bien.nceas.ucsb.edu/bien/biendata)
exact match: Leaf lifespan (longevity) [TRY:12] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
exact match: Leaf life span [TOP254] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Leaf lifespan is the inverse of the rate of leaf turnover. For some species, leaflets or other portions of a leaf may be censused rather than the entire leaf lamina. Leaf lifespan can be censused as either the rate of shedding leaves (leaf death) or the rate of formation of new leaves (leaf birth).

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Categorical descriptions of a taxon's relative stature in its community, used to assess competitive heirarchies within a community.

A classification [NCIT:C25161] that indicates the vegetation layer [ENVO:01000355] a taxon [NCIT:C40098] reaches within its community [ECSO:00000310], used to assess competition [EnvThes:21097] within the community.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Categorical descriptions of a taxon's relative stature in its community, used to assess competitive heirarchies within a community.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: UnderstoreyCanopy [PalmTraits] (https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-019-0189-0)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Binary variable describing whether a plant has the capacity for nitrogen fixatation, indicating it engages in symbioses with microorganisms (most commonly bacteria or cyanobacteria) that are capable of nitrogen fixation. Nitrogen fixation capacity is usually identified by nodules on the plant roots.

A trait which indicates whether a plant has the capacity to engage in symbioses [GO:0044403] with microorganisms [NCIT:C14329] (bacteria [NCIT:C14187], cyanobacteria [NCBITaxon:1117], and fungi [NCBITaxon:4751]) capable of nitrogen fixation [GO:0009399] and usually identified by nodulation [GO:0009877] on the plant roots [PO:0009005].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Binary variable describing whether a plant has the capacity for nitrogen fixatation, indicating it engages in symbioses with microorganisms (most commonly bacteria or cyanobacteria) that are capable of nitrogen fixation. Nitrogen fixation capacity is usually identified by nodules on the plant roots.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Nutritional relationships [BROT:18] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Specific specialized types of root structures and root symbioses, especially symbioses with mycorrhizal fungi.
A trait which indicates types [NCIT:C25284] of root [PO:0009005] structures [PATO:0000141], including structures associated with mutualisms [GO:0085030] with mycorrhizae [EnvThes:20656].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Specific specialized types of root structures and root symbioses, especially symbioses with mycorrhizal fungi.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Trait indicating whether a plant forms haustoria and obtains part or all of its energy-rich carbon compounds (photosynthetic sugars), mineral nutrition and/or water directly from another plant (its host) in an interaction that does not benefit the host plant.

A whole plant [PO:0000003] phenotype [NCIT:C16977] trait that indicates if a plant is involved in a parasitic [ECOCORE:00000146] symbiosis [ECOCORE:00000022] where it forms haustorium [GO:0085035] on a host [GO:0018995] plant and the host plant provides all or some of its high energy [PATO:0001021] carbon [CHEBI:27594] compounds [NCIT:C43366], mineral nutrition (nutrients [CHEBI:33284]) and/or water [CHEBI:15377].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Trait indicating whether a plant forms haustoria and obtains part or all of its energy-rich carbon compounds (photosynthetic sugars), mineral nutrition and/or water directly from another plant (its host) in an interaction that does not benefit the host plant.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Nutritional relationships [BROT:18] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
close match: Parasite_1 [GIFT:1.5.1] (https://gift.uni-goettingen.de)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Plants described as parasitic in the context of this trait always have haustoria, specialised organs that penetrate the host plants's vascular bundles. The trait `root_structures` documents symbiotic relationships with fungi. The trait `plant_energy_acquisition_strategy` documents specialised strategies or specialised organs or tissues plants use to obtain carbon or mineral nutrition.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Months during which taxon has leaves.
A plant phenological trait [TO:0000933] which is the months [UO:0000035] during which a plant [PO:0000003] has leaves [PO:0025034].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Trait keyed as a sequences of 12 Ns (without foliage) and Ys (with foliage), representing the 12 months, starting with January.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Plant sex type, indicating, for a taxon the type of flowers (male, female, and hermaphroditic) present on individual plants versus separate plants within a population.

A plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839] which is the distribution [PATO:0000060] of male [PATO:0000384], female [PATO:0000383], and hermaphroditic [PATO:0001340] flowers [PO:0009046] on one individual [EFO:0000542] and across multiple individuals in a population [PCO:0000001].

A classification [NCIT:C25161] based on a taxon's [NCIT:C40098] flower morphology traits [TO:0000499] that indicates the taxa (biotic vectors) or abiotic mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] that most likely pollinate [GO:0009856] a flower [PO:0009046].

The total mass [PATO:0000125] of chromosomes [NCIT:C13202] that comprise a plant's genome [OMIT:0027643] in a somatic cell [CL:0002371].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Chromosome ploidy, the number of copies of each chromosome present in a somatic cell.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The age of a plant when they are able to set seed, indicating it is reproductively mature.

The age [NCIT:C25150] of a plant when it is capable of sexual reproduction [GO:0000003], which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] between seed germination [GO:0009845] and when a plant is able to produce mature [PATO:0001701] seed [PO:0009010].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The age of a plant when they are able to set seed, indicating it is reproductively mature.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Age at maturity of saplings [BROT:42] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
exact match: whole plant primary juvenile period length [BIEN] (https://bien.nceas.ucsb.edu/bien/biendata)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Although reproductive maturity should be marked by the ability to set viable seed, this trait will often be scored as when plants first produce flowers, as this is easier to score. This trait is only meant to capture primary reproductive maturity, not secondary reproductive maturity following a disturbance. See a series of traits starting with `fire_time_from_fire_to_flowering` and `fire_time_from_fire_to_fruiting` for measures of secondary reproductive maturity.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Plant dispersal syndromes are generally assigned to species based on suites of diaspore characteristics associated with specific mechanisms of dispersal. Trait values are mostly given as the formal dispersal syndromes ending in 'chory', a suffix meaning 'a specified method of plant dispersal'.

A classification [NCIT:C25161] based on a taxon's [NCIT:C40098] seed morphology traits [TO:0000184] or fruit morphology traits [TO:0002629] that indicates the taxa (biotic vectors) or abiotic mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] that most likely disperse [OMIT: 0027297] seeds [PO:0009010] and fruit [PO:0009001] away from the parent plant.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Plant dispersal syndromes are generally assigned to species based on suites of diaspore characteristics associated with specific mechanisms of dispersal. Trait values are mostly given as the formal dispersal syndromes ending in 'chory', a suffix meaning 'a specified method of plant dispersal'.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Dispersal mode [BROT:23] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
exact match: whole plant dispersal syndrome [BIEN] (https://bien.nceas.ucsb.edu/bien/biendata)
exact match: Dispersal syndrome [GIFT:3.3] (https://gift.uni-goettingen.de)
exact match: Dispersal syndrome [TRY:28] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
exact match: Plant dispersal syndrome [TOP346] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Dominant diaspore dispersal agents, including both biotic agents (specific taxa) or abiotic mechanisms responsible for dispersing seeds (or other dispersal units) away from the parent plant.
The taxa [NCIT:C40098] (biotic vectors) and abiotic mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] that disperse [OMIT: 0027297] seeds [PO:0009010] and fruit [PO:0009001] away from a parent plant.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Dominant diaspore dispersal agents, including both biotic agents (specific taxa) or abiotic mechanisms responsible for dispersing seeds (or other dispersal units) away from the parent plant.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Dispersal syndrome [TRY:28] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
close match: Plant dispersal syndrome [TOP346] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Allowable terms for biotic dispersal agents include taxa at both the species-level and much broader groupings, reflecting both the different levels of resolution provided by researchers and whether a plant has specific versus broad dispersal agents. Abiotic dispersal mechanisms can likewise be quite general or specific, depending on data availability.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A plants' flowering response to unpredictable, irregular environmental cues.
Unpredictable, irregular environmental conditions [ENVO_01000203] that are linked to a plant [PO:0000003] producing flowers [PO:0009046].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A plants' flowering response to unpredictable, irregular environmental cues.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Taxa may be scored as having an environmental flowering cue, but also display a season-specific flowering response which is captured in the trait `flowering_time`. For additional details on a plant's post-fire flowering response see also the trait `post_fire_flowering`.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Months during which taxon has open (anthetic) flowers.
The months [UO:0000035] during which a plant [PO:0000003] has open (anthetic) flowers [PO:0009046] and is therefore at the whole plant flowering stage [PO:0007016].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Months during which taxon has open (anthetic) flowers.

related match: Plant flowering begin trait [TOP292] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Trait keyed as a sequences of 12 Ns (not flowering) and Ys (flowering), representing the 12 months, starting with January.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Months during which taxon produces fruit with mature seeds.
The months [UO:0000035] during which a plant [PO:0000003] produces fruit [PO:0009001] with mature [PATO:0001701] seeds [PO:0009010].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Months during which taxon produces fruit with mature seeds.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: plant fruiting duration [BIEN] (https://bien.nceas.ucsb.edu/bien/biendata)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Trait keyed as a sequences of 12 Ns (not fruiting) and Ys (fruiting), representing the 12 months, starting with January.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The months during which seed germination and seedling establishment occurs.
The months [UO:0000035] during which seed [PO:0009010] germination [GO:0009845] and seedling establishment [EnvThes:20410] occurs.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The months during which seed germination and seedling establishment occurs.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Trait keyed as a sequences of 12 Ns (not recruiting) and Ys (recruiting), representing the 12 months, starting with January.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The environmental conditions under which a taxon's seedlings can establish, with trait values reflecting successional changes to the vegetation community.

The environmental conditions [ENVO:01000203] under which a taxon [NCIT:C40098] displays seed [PO:0009010] germination [GO:0009845] and seedling establishment [EnvThes:20410], with trait values reflecting successional changes to the vegetation community.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The environmental conditions under which a taxon's seedlings can establish, with trait values reflecting successional changes to the vegetation community.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: related match: Seedling establishment [TRY:3620] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: The selection of trait values does not distinguish between the ability to establish in intermediate age versus mature vegetation, as this level of detail is rarely provided in datasets.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The minimum light environment required by plants for reproduction, scaled from 0 to 8.

A plant phenological [TO:0000933] life history [ECOCORE:00000018] trait which is an index [NCIT:C25390] that captures the level of photosynthetically active radiation [ENVO:01001864] required by plants for reproduction [GO:0000003].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The minimum light environment required by plants for reproduction, scaled from 0 to 8.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: related match: Species light requirement [TRY:788] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: 0 indicates `No direct light, extremely low levels of transmitted/reflected light, such as beneath dense fern or palm fronds close to ground level.`; 0.5 indicates `No direct light, very low levels of transmitted light`; 1 indicates `Rare or no exposure to direct light from lateral sources, and low levels of transmitted light.`; 2 indicates `Low lateral light and low-moderate transmitted light with <10% of inverted cone exposed to lateral sources of direct light, plus low to moderate levels of transmitted light`; 3 indicates `Low-moderate lateral & moderate transmitted light, with <5% exposure of the focal crown to vertical direct light, and <15 % of inverted cone exposed to lateral sources of direct light, plus moderate transmitted light.`; 4 indicates `Moderate lateral light & moderate-high transmitted light, with 5 - 10% exposure of focal crown to direct vertical light, plus 2-20% exposure of inverted cone to lateral sources of direct light, plus moderate to high levels of transmitted light.`; 5 indicates `Moderate vertical light and moderate-high lateral light, with 5 - 20% exposure of focal crown to direct vertical light, plus one or both of, i. 10-40% exposure of 90-degree inverted cone to lateral sources of direct light, ii. exposure to high levels of transmitted light`; 6 indicates `Moderate-High vertical and high lateral light, with 10-30% of vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light, and lateral light exposure for > 40% of 90-degree inverted cone`, 7 indicates `High vertical and lateral light, with 30-80% of vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light, or exposure to lateral sources of direct light for > 60 % of a 90-degree inverted cone encompassing the focal crown.`; 8 indicates `Full light exposure of crown, with > 80% of the vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light.`.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Canopy light environment required for reproduction

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The minimum light environment required by seedlings for establishment, scaled from 0 to 8.

A plant phenological [TO:0000933] life history [ECOCORE:00000018] trait which is an index [NCIT:C25390] that captures the level of photosynthetically active radiation [ENVO:01001864] required by plants for seed germination [GO:0009845] and seedling establishment [EnvThes:20410].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The minimum light environment required by seedlings for establishment, scaled from 0 to 8.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: related match: Species light requirement [TRY:788] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: 0 indicates `No direct light, extremely low levels of transmitted/reflected light, such as beneath dense fern or palm fronds close to ground level.`; 0.5 indicates `No direct light, very low levels of transmitted light`; 1 indicates `Rare or no exposure to direct light from lateral sources, and low levels of transmitted light.`; 2 indicates `Low lateral light and low-moderate transmitted light with <10% of inverted cone exposed to lateral sources of direct light, plus low to moderate levels of transmitted light`; 3 indicates `Low-moderate lateral & moderate transmitted light, with <5% exposure of the focal crown to vertical direct light, and <15 % of inverted cone exposed to lateral sources of direct light, plus moderate transmitted light.`; 4 indicates `Moderate lateral light & moderate-high transmitted light, with 5 - 10% exposure of focal crown to direct vertical light, plus 2-20% exposure of inverted cone to lateral sources of direct light, plus moderate to high levels of transmitted light.`; 5 indicates `Moderate vertical light and moderate-high lateral light, with 5 - 20% exposure of focal crown to direct vertical light, plus one or both of, i. 10-40% exposure of 90-degree inverted cone to lateral sources of direct light, ii. exposure to high levels of transmitted light`; 6 indicates `Moderate-High vertical and high lateral light, with 10-30% of vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light, and lateral light exposure for > 40% of 90-degree inverted cone`, 7 indicates `High vertical and lateral light, with 30-80% of vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light, or exposure to lateral sources of direct light for > 60 % of a 90-degree inverted cone encompassing the focal crown.`; 8 indicates `Full light exposure of crown, with > 80% of the vertical projection of the crown exposed to vertical light.`.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Canopy light environment required for seedling establishment

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Location of a plant's seedbank, the location where mature seeds are stored and viable until germinating.

The location [NCIT:C25341] of a plant's [PO:0000003] seedbank [MESH:D000068098], indicating locations where mature [PATO:0001701] seeds [PO:0009010] are stored and remain viable [PATO:0000169] until germination [GO:0009845].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Location of a plant's seedbank, the location where mature seeds are stored and viable until germinating.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Seedbank type [TRY:159] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Related traits include `seed_longevity`, and `serotiny`.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Categorical variable describing whether a fruit or cone remains closed in the plant canopy after maturation until an environmental cue, usually a fire, but possibly also drought or extreme heat, triggers it to release its seeds.

A fire response trait which indicates whether a fruit [PO:0009001] or cone [strobilus; PO:0025083] remains closed in the canopy [ENVO:01001242] after maturation [TO:0002661], with the seed [PO:0009010] only being released [NCIT:C42882] after a specific [NCIT:C38024] environmental conditions [ENVO:01000203], usually an environmental cue associated with a fire [ENVO:01000786], but possibly also drought or extreme heat.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Categorical variable describing whether a fruit or cone remains closed in the plant canopy after maturation until an environmental cue, usually a fire, but possibly also drought or extreme heat, triggers it to release its seeds.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Serotiny level [BROT:39] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
close match: Seedbank type [TRY:159] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Categorical groupings indicating the length of time (duration) a mature seed remains in the seedbank, viable and able to germinate.

A seedbank's  [MESH:D000068098] longevity [EnvThes:22228], expressed as a categorical variable [STATO:0000252], where seedbank longevity is the time interval (duration [PATO:0001309]) a mature [PATO:0001701] seed [PO:0009010] remains in the seedbank, viable [PATO_0000169] and able to germinate [GO:0009845].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Categorical groupings indicating the length of time (duration) a mature seed remains in the seedbank, viable and able to germinate.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Soil seed bank longevity [BROT:40] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
close match: Canopy seed bank longevity [BROT:38] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Seedbank longevity classes are a feature of a `population` (sample) of seeds, not an individual seed. Also see the traits `seedbank_longevity` (numeric trait), `seed_dormancy_class` and the trait `seed_recruitment_timing`.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The half-life of the seedbank, which is the length of time (duration) from when seeds in a seedbank mature until more than half the seeds in a seedbank are no longer able to germinate.

The half-life of the seedbank [MESH:D000068098], with is the  time interval (duration [PATO:0001309]) from when seeds [PO:0009010] in a seedbank mature [PATO:0001701] until more than half the seeds in a seedbank are no longer able to germinate [GO:0009845].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The half-life of the seedbank, which is the length of time (duration) from when seeds in a seedbank mature until more than half the seeds in a seedbank are no longer able to germinate.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Soil seed bank longevity [BROT:40] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
close match: Canopy seed bank longevity [BROT:38] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: Seedbank longevity can only be measured on a `population` (sample) of seeds, not on an individual seed. Also see the traits `seedbank_longevity_class`,  `seed_dormancy_class` and `seed_recruitment_timing`.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Mechanisms that inhibit mature seeds from germinating and the environmental or experimental cues that allow a seed to break dormancy and germinate.
Physical [PATO:0002079], physiological [NCIT:C16990], and morphological [PATO:0000051] mechanisms [NCIT:C25343] that inhibit mature [PATO:0001701] seeds [PO:0009010] from germinating [GO:0009845].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Mechanisms that inhibit mature seeds from germinating and the environmental or experimental cues that allow a seed to break dormancy and germinate.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Other germination cues [BROT:37] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
close match: Heat-stimulated germination [BROT:36] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
close match: Chemical germination cues [BROT:35] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Treatment required for seed to display high germination rates. The data included in AusTraits are mostly from seed banks that have recorded the protocols they use to encourage seeds to germinate. The treatments may therefore be only loosely connected to the cues required for a species' to break dormancy.
The treatment [EFO:0000727] or experimental conditions [XCO:0000000] required for a high [NCIT:C25227] proportion [PATO:0001470] of seeds [PO:0009010] to germinate [GO:0009845] .

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Treatment required for seed to display high germination rates. The data included in AusTraits are mostly from seed banks that have recorded the protocols they use to encourage seeds to germinate. The treatments may therefore be only loosely connected to the cues required for a species' to break dormancy.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Other germination cues [BROT:37] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
close match: Heat-stimulated germination [BROT:36] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
close match: Chemical germination cues [BROT:35] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
exact match: Seed germination stimulation [TRY:34] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Proportion of mature seeds in a sample that germinated under specified environmental or experimental conditions.

The proportion [PATO:0001470] of mature [PATO:0001701] seeds [PO:0009010] in a sample that germinated [GO:0009845] under the specified [NCIT:C38024] environmental conditions [ENVO:01000203] or experimental conditions [XCO:0000000].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Proportion of mature seeds in a sample that germinated under specified environmental or experimental conditions.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Seed germination rate (germination efficiency) [TRY:95] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Proportion of mature seeds in a sample that are capable of germinating under suitable conditions.

The proportion [PATO:0001470] of mature [PATO:0001701] seeds [PO:0009010] that are capable of germinating [GO:0009845] under suitable [NCIT:C116358] environmental conditions [ENVO:01000203] or experimental conditions [XCO:0000000] .

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Proportion of mature seeds in a sample that are capable of germinating under suitable conditions.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Seed viability [TRY:1109](https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The time interval from when a seed is exposed to suitable conditions for germinating until it germinates.

The time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] from when a seed [PO:0009010] is exposed to suitable [NCIT:C116358] environmental conditions [ENVO:01000203] or experimental conditions [XCO:0000000] for germinating  [GO:0009845] until it germinates.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The time interval from when a seed is exposed to suitable conditions for germinating until it germinates.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A binary trait, indicating whether a plant taxon is able to reproduce and spread through the growth and division of vegetative material.

A whole plant [PO:0000003] life history [ECOCORE:00000018] trait which is the ability [NCIT:C78209] of individual [EFO:0000542] plants to reproduce [GO:0000003] through asexual reproduction [GO:0019954] (vegetative reproduction).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A binary trait, indicating whether a plant taxon is able to reproduce and spread through the growth and division of vegetative material.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Clonality [BROT:15] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
exact match: Reproduction_asexual_1 [GIFT:3.5.1] (https://gift.uni-goettingen.de)
exact match: Plant vegetative regeneration capacity [TRY:344] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
exact match: Plant reproduction type [TOP123] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: For plants able to reproduce vegetatively, more detailed information about the mechanisms and structures that allow clonal spread is provided in the trait `clonal_spread_mechanism`. The trait `dispersal_unit` captures information on plants that never produce by seed.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Mechanisms and structures (tissues, organs, or other structures) a plant uses to spread vegetatively, including the production of clones.

A plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839] which is the mechanism [NCIT:C25343] plants use for clonal growth [EnvThes:21032] (asexual reproduction [GO:0019954]) or for regeneration [GO:0031099] after a disturbance event [EnvThes:20373]

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Mechanisms and structures (tissues, organs, or other structures) a plant uses to spread vegetatively, including the production of clones.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Clonality [BROT:15] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
exact match: Reproduction_asexual_2 [GIFT:3.5.2] (https://gift.uni-goettingen.de)
exact match: Plant vegetative reproduction: clonal growth organ [TRY:356] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: See `vegetative_reproduction_ability` for a binary description of whether a plant can spread vegetatively. There are two other traits with overlapping trait values, but that are distinct trait concepts: `storage_organ` indicates the plant structures where a plant stores excess carbohydrates; these organs may or may not facilitate clonal spread; `bud_bank_location` indicates the location of meristematic tissue (buds) that allow regeneration following a disturbance or after an annual unfavourable season.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Plant structures  (tissues, organs, or other structures) where a plant stores excess carbohydrates (energy). The stored energy may be used for future growth, including clonal spread and regrowth following an annual unfavourable season, or for regrowth following a disturbance event (including post-fire regeneration or another disturbance event that causes leaf loss). Trait values include both generic terms and quite specific ones to accommodate the variation in detail provided across datasets.

A plant structure morphology trait [TO:0000839] which is the type [NCIT:C25284] of storage organ [EFO:0000997] a plant has, where a storage organ is a plant part (organ [PO:0009008], tissue [PO:0009007], or other plant structure [PO:0009011]) whose function [NCIT:C25518] is carbohydrate [CHEBI:16646] (energy [PATO:0001021]) storage.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Plant structures  (tissues, organs, or other structures) where a plant stores excess carbohydrates (energy). The stored energy may be used for future growth, including clonal spread and regrowth following an annual unfavourable season, or for regrowth following a disturbance event (including post-fire regeneration or another disturbance event that causes leaf loss). Trait values include both generic terms and quite specific ones to accommodate the variation in detail provided across datasets.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Plant storage organ [TOP166] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: There are two other traits with overlapping trait values, but that are distinct trait concepts: `clonal_spread_mechanism` indicates mechanisms and structures a plant actually uses for vegetative spread; not all energy storage organs also allow vegetative spread; `bud_bank_location` indicates the location of meristematic tissue (buds) that allow regeneration following a disturbance or after an annual unfavourable season. See Pausus, Lamont et al. 2018 (doi.org/10.1111/nph.14982) for detailed descriptions of recolonization ability and level of fire protection provided by each regeneration strategy.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The location of buds (meristematic tissue) on a plant that allows it to resprout following a fire, annual unfavourable season, or other disturbance event, such as a drought or cyclone. Trait values include both generic terms and quite specific ones to accommodate the variation in detail provided across datasets.

The position [PATO:0000140] and distribution [PATO:0000060] of vegetative meristematic tissue [PO:0006079] (buds [PO:0000055]) on a plant [PO:0000003]. These may be buds that allow a plant to regrow following an unfavourable season or buds that survive [EnvThes:21064] a disturbance event [EnvThes:20373] such as a fire, cyclone or drought. In particular, they may be meristematic tissue that survives a fire [ENVO:01000786] and allows the plant to resprout [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout] following the fire.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The location of buds (meristematic tissue) on a plant that allows it to resprout following a fire, annual unfavourable season, or other disturbance event, such as a drought or cyclone. Trait values include both generic terms and quite specific ones to accommodate the variation in detail provided across datasets.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Bud source [BROT:30] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: There are two other traits with overlapping trait values, but that are distinct trait concepts: `clonal_spread_mechanism` indicates mechanisms and structures a plant actually uses for vegetative spread; not all energy storage organs also allow vegetative spread; `storage_organ` indicates the plant structures where a plant stores excess carbohydrates. See Pausus, Lamont et al. 2018 (doi.org/10.1111/nph.14982) for detailed descriptions of recolonization ability and level of fire protection provided by each regeneration strategy. If specific bud banks only survive some types of disturbance, the disturbance should be specified as a context property.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Depth below the soil surface (positive number) or height above ground (negative number) from which buds (meristematic tissue) resprout following a disturbance, such as a fire.

The depth [PATO:0001595] below the ground [SWEET:realmSoil/Ground] surface or height [PATO:0000119] above the ground surface of vegetative meristematic tissue [PO:0006079] (buds [PO:0000055]) that resprouts [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout] following a fire [ENVO:01000786].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Depth below the soil surface (positive number) or height above ground (negative number) from which buds (meristematic tissue) resprout following a disturbance, such as a fire.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Budbank height distribution [TRY:153] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Trait indicating whether mature individuals of a taxon are killed, resprout, or have a mixed survival response when exposed to fire that causes 100% leaf scorch.  Species where at least 70% of plants resprout are designated `resprouters`, while those where fewer than 30% of plants resprout are designated as `fire killed`. Species with an intermediate response have a mixed fire response, and are coded as `fire_killed resprouts`.

A fire response trait which indicates whether mature [PATO:0001701] plants [PO:0000003] from a taxon [NCIT:C40098] or population [PCO:0000001] are killed or have vegetative meristematic tissue [PO:0006079] (buds [PO:0000055]) that resprout [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout] following a fire [ENVO:01000786] that causes 100% leaf scorch, with fire severity index [EnvThes:22120] an important contextual variable.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Trait indicating whether mature individuals of a taxon are killed, resprout, or have a mixed survival response when exposed to fire that causes 100% leaf scorch.  Species where at least 70% of plants resprout are designated `resprouters`, while those where fewer than 30% of plants resprout are designated as `fire killed`. Species with an intermediate response have a mixed fire response, and are coded as `fire_killed resprouts`.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Resprouting capacity after fire [BROT:34] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
exact match: Plant resprouting capacity [TRY:819] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
exact match: Species tolerance to fire [TRY:318] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait is narrowly applicable only to taxa that experience fire; see the trait `fire_exposure_level` for trait values related to species whose strategy is to avoid fire.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#scop.@value: applicable to plants that experience fire

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Proportion of mature individuals in a population that survive a fire and resprout following a fire.

A fire response trait which is the proportion [PATO:0001470] of mature [PATO:0001701] individuals [EFO:0000542] in a population [PCO:0000001] that have vegetative meristematic tissue [PO:0006079] (buds [PO:0000055]) that resprouts [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout] following a fire [ENVO:01000786].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Proportion of mature individuals in a population that survive a fire and resprout following a fire.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Plant resprouting capacity [TRY:819] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
exact match: Species tolerance to fire [TRY:318] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#scop.@value: applicable to plants that experience fire

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Trait indicating whether juvenile phase individuals of a taxon are killed, resprout, or have a mixed survival response when exposed to a fire with 100% leaf scorch.

A fire response trait which indicates whether juvenile [PATO:0001190] plants [PO:0000003] from a taxon [NCIT:C40098] or population [PCO:0000001] are killed or have vegetative meristematic tissue [PO:0006079] (buds [PO:0000055]) that resprouts [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout] following a fire [ENVO:01000786] with 100% leaf scorch.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Trait indicating whether juvenile phase individuals of a taxon are killed, resprout, or have a mixed survival response when exposed to a fire with 100% leaf scorch.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Plant resprouting capacity [TRY:819] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
close match: Species tolerance to fire [TRY:318] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Post-fire resprouting capacity of juvenile plants

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#scop.@value: applicable to plants that experience fire

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A fire response trait which is the time from seed germination until individuals are able to survive and resprout following a fire where 100% of the leaves in the canopy are scorched.

A fire response trait which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] from seed germination [GO:0009845] until individuals [EFO:0000542] are able to survive [EnvThes:21064] and resprout [PlantResprout] following a fire where 100% of the leaves [PO:0025034] in the canopy [ENVO:01001242] are scorched.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A fire response trait which is the time from seed germination until individuals are able to survive and resprout following a fire where 100% of the leaves in the canopy are scorched.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: An essential context property to map for this trait is the population survival metric. For instance, is this trait scored based on the youngest individual to survive a fire or the age at which 50% of individuals survive and resprout following a fire.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Time from seedling germination until individuals survive a fire

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#scop.@value: applicable to plants that resprout following fire at some life stages

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Ratio of stem count post-fire to basal stem count (e.g. grass tillers) pre-fire at an individual or population level. This trait is appropriate to score for plants that have many stems from the base (shrubs, herbs, graminoids) where the number of stems is censused both before and after the fire. It is a continuous measure of resprouting strength conditioned on initial size.

A fire response trait which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the count [NCIT:C25463] of stems [PO:0009047] per individual [EFO:0000542] following a fire [ENVO:01000786] to the count of stems per individual before the fire, recorded for taxa that have multiple stems emerging from the ground [SWEET:realmSoil/Ground].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Ratio of stem count post-fire to basal stem count (e.g. grass tillers) pre-fire at an individual or population level. This trait is appropriate to score for plants that have many stems from the base (shrubs, herbs, graminoids) where the number of stems is censused both before and after the fire. It is a continuous measure of resprouting strength conditioned on initial size.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait will usually be recorded in natural or experimental systems subjected to a controlled burn, where stem counts can be censused both before and after a fire. However, it is appropriate to include data for any plants subjected to fire where the dead stems can still be counted post-fire.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#scop.@value: applicable to plants that experience fire

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A plant's ability to regenerate vegetatively (resprout) from a disturbance other than fire that causes 100% defoliation.

A whole plant [PO:0000003] life history [ECOCORE:00000018] trait which is the ability [NCIT:C78209] of individual [EFO:0000542] plants to regenerate [GO:0031099] vegetatively (resprout [Cerrado:fire#PlantResprout]) from meristematic tissue [PO:0006079], buds [PO:0000055]) after a disturbance event [EnvThes:20373] other than a fire [ENVO:01000786] that causes 100% defoliation.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A plant's ability to regenerate vegetatively (resprout) from a disturbance other than fire that causes 100% defoliation.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Resprouting capacity after clipping [BROT:32] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
exact match: Resprouting capacity after disturbances [BROT:33] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait explicitly refers to a plant's vegetative regeneration ability following a disturbance event other than fire. See other `resprouting_capacity` traits, `bud_bank_location`, and `clonal_spread_mechanism` for other information about a plant's ability to resprout. Just as post-fire resprouting capacity is documented in individuals that have suffered 100% leaf scorch, this trait should be scored only on individuals that have suffered 100% leaf loss. If a different leaf loss percentage is used, this needs to be documented as a context property.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Plant vegetative response to disturbances other than fire

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Trait indicating habitat (or microhabitat) variation that protects the shoot or root system of some taxa from being exposed to fire and scorched by the fire, even when a fire burns nearby.

A fire response trait indicating small-scale variation in plant [PO:0000003] habitat [ENVO:01000739] or growing season that protects the plant's shoot systems [PO:0009006] or root system [PO:0025025] from exposure [NCIT:C17941] to fire [ENVO:01000786] or being damaged (scorched) by fire, when a fire occurs nearby.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Trait indicating habitat (or microhabitat) variation that protects the shoot or root system of some taxa from being exposed to fire and scorched by the fire, even when a fire burns nearby.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: A trait indicating the magnitude of seed germination and seedling establishment following a fire.
A fire response trait which is the magnitude [NCIT:C49158] of seed [PO:0009010] germination [GO:0009845] and seedling establishment [EnvThes:20410] after a fire [ENVO:01000786].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A trait indicating the magnitude of seed germination and seedling establishment following a fire.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: related match: Post-fire seedling survival [BROT:44] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)
exact match: Post-fire seedling emergence [BROT:43] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait does not suggest what mechanism(s) is triggering post-fire recruitment, but only that a post-fire response is (or is not) observed. There are several fire-related context properties that should be documented whenever possible, including fire severity (most important), fire season, and fire frequency. In addition, the time from fire to recruitment will vary greatly across systems, and, when available, a basic habitat description should be documented as a location property.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Indication of whether the magnitude of flowers produced by a taxon increases, decreases or remains unchanged following a fire.

A fire response trait which is a taxon's [NCIT:C40098] flowering [PO:0007016] response [NCIT:C25755] to fire [ENVO:01000786], indicating if the magnitude [NCIT_C49158] of flowers [PO:0009046] increases, decreases or remains unchanged following a fire.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Indication of whether the magnitude of flowers produced by a taxon increases, decreases or remains unchanged following a fire.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Fire-stimulated flowering [BROT:31] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait does not suggest what mechanism(s) is triggering post-fire flowering, but only that a post-fire response is (or is not) observed. There are several fire-related context properties that should be documented whenever possible, including fire severity (most important), fire season, and fire frequency. In addition, the time from fire to flowering will vary greatly across systems, and, when available, a basic habitat description should be documented as a location property.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The time interval from a fire until the first individual in a population begins flowering.

A fire response trait which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] after a fire [ENVO:01000786] until one individual [EFO:0000542] of a taxon [NCIT:C40098] in a population  [PCO:0000001] reaches whole plant flowering stage [PO_0007016].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The time interval from a fire until the first individual in a population begins flowering.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Age at maturity of resprouts [BROT:41] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait can include data that documents the time from a fire until either a resprouter or a fire-killed species first begins flowering, as both have important regeneration and conservation implications. Whenever available, a context property should be added to indicate if data are scoring the time from seed germination or post-fire resprouting to the onset of flowering.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Time from fire to first flowering

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The time interval from a fire until 50% of the individuals in a population produce flowers.

A fire response trait which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] after a fire [ENVO:01000786] until a 50% of the individuals  [EFO:0000542] of a taxon [NCIT:C40098] in a population  [PCO:0000001] reaches whole plant flowering stage [PO_0007016].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The time interval from a fire until 50% of the individuals in a population produce flowers.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Age at maturity of resprouts [BROT:41] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait can include data that documents the time from a fire until either a resprouter or a fire-killed species first begins flowering, as both have important regeneration and conservation implications. Whenever available, a context property should be added to indicate if data are scoring the time from seed germination or post-fire resprouting to the onset of flowering.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Time from fire until 50% of individuals are flowering

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The time interval from a fire until the individuals in a population display maximum flowering.

A fire response trait which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] after a fire [ENVO:01000786] until the individuals [EFO:0000542] of a taxon [NCIT:C40098] in a population  [PCO:0000001] reach maximum flowering [PO_0007016] levels.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The time interval from a fire until the individuals in a population display maximum flowering.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Age at maturity of resprouts [BROT:41] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait can include data that documents the time from a fire until either a resprouter or a fire-killed species first begins flowering, as both have important regeneration and conservation implications. Whenever available, a context property should be added to indicate if data are scoring the time from seed germination or post-fire resprouting to the onset of flowering.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Time from fire to peak flowering

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The time interval from a fire until the degree of flowering by individuals in a population begin to decline.

A fire response trait which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] after a fire [ENVO:01000786] until the individuals [EFO:0000542] of a taxon [NCIT:C40098] in a population  [PCO:0000001] begin to decrease their level of flowering [PO_0007016].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The time interval from a fire until the degree of flowering by individuals in a population begin to decline.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Age at maturity of resprouts [BROT:41] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Time from fire until flowering declines

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The time interval from a fire until the first individual in a population produces a mature fruit with viable propagules.

A fire response trait which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] after a fire [ENVO:01000786] until one individual [EFO:0000542] of a taxon [NCIT:C40098] in a population  [PCO:0000001] produces mature [PATO:0001701] fruit [PO:0009001].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The time interval from a fire until the first individual in a population produces a mature fruit with viable propagules.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Age at maturity of resprouts [BROT:41] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: This trait can include data that documents the time from a fire until either a resprouter or a fire-killed species first begins producing mature fruit, as both have important regeneration and conservation implications. Whenever available, a context property should be added to indicate if data are scoring the time from seed germination or post-fire resprouting to the onset of fruiting.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The time interval from a fire until 50% of the individuals in a population produce mature fruit.

A fire response trait which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] after a fire [ENVO:01000786] until a 50% of the individuals  [EFO:0000542] of a taxon [NCIT:C40098] in a population  [PCO:0000001] produce mature [PATO:0001701] fruit [PO:0009001].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The time interval from a fire until 50% of the individuals in a population produce mature fruit.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Age at maturity of resprouts [BROT:41] (http://doi.org/10.1038/sdata.2018.135)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#pref.@value: Time from fire until 50% of individuals are fruiting

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The density of the fuel bed, the plant litter accumulated on the ground. It is calculated as the ratio of the mass of the fuel bed to the fuel bed volume. This trait should be measured on plant litter from a single taxon.

Fuel bed bulk density (volume density [PATO:0001353]), which is the ratio [PATO:0001470] of the mass [PATO:0000125] of the fuel bed divided by the fuel bed volume [PATO:0000918]; the term `fuel bed` refers to the accumulated plant litter [ENVO:01000628] on the ground [SWEET:realmSoil/Ground], as this is the fuel [CHEBI:33292] that is burnt in a ground fire [ENVO:01000786].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The density of the fuel bed, the plant litter accumulated on the ground. It is calculated as the ratio of the mass of the fuel bed to the fuel bed volume. This trait should be measured on plant litter from a single taxon.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: In wildland environments it will be difficult to measure this trait on an individual taxon and fuel bed will instead be a 'community level' trait. Therefore, this trait will generally be used to document fuel bed bulk density in experimental situations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Proportion of available plant biomass (live and dead) that is consumed by fire. This trait should be measured on biomass from a single taxon.
For a given taxon [NCIT:C40098], the proportion [PATO:0001470] of plant biomass [ENVO:01000155] (fuel [CHEBI:33292]) that is consumed by a fire [ENVO:01000786].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Proportion of available plant biomass (live and dead) that is consumed by fire. This trait should be measured on biomass from a single taxon.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: In wildland environments it will be difficult to measure this trait on an individual taxon; it will instead be a 'community level' trait. Therefore, this trait will generally be used to document fuel consumption in experimental situations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: The horizontal rate of fire spread.
For a given taxon [NCIT:C40098], the horizontal [PATO:0001855] speed [PATO:0000008] of fire [ENVO:01000786] movement [NCIT:C37994].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The horizontal rate of fire spread.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: In wildland environments it will be difficult to measure this trait on an individual taxon; it will instead be a 'community level' trait. Therefore, this trait will generally be used to document rates of fire spread in experimental situations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Smoulder duration for a single leaf, which is the time from the end of the last visible flame until the glowing phase dies out.

A fire response trait which is the duration [PATO:0001309] of the portion of fire [ENVO:01000786]-induced combustion [NCIT:C157201] process from the time when a flame [ENVO:01000789] is no longer visible until smoulder combustion ends.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Smoulder duration for a single leaf, which is the time from the end of the last visible flame until the glowing phase dies out.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: In wildland environments it will be difficult to measure this trait on an individual taxon; it will instead be a 'community level' trait. Therefore, this trait will generally be used to document rates of fire spread in experimental situations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Flame duration for a single leaf, which is the time from the first visible flame until the last visible flame.

A fire response trait which is the duration [PATO:0001309] of the portion of fire [ENVO:01000786]-induced combustion [NCIT:C157201] process from the start of combustion until a flame [ENVO:01000789] is no longer visible.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Flame duration for a single leaf, which is the time from the first visible flame until the last visible flame.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: In wildland environments it will be difficult to measure this trait on an individual taxon; it will instead be a 'community level' trait. Therefore, this trait will generally be used to document rates of fire spread in experimental situations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: For a single leaf, the sum of flame duration and smoulder duration, which is the time from the first visible flame until the glowing phase dies out.

A fire response trait which is the duration [PATO:0001309] of the entire fire [ENVO:01000786]-induced combustion [NCIT:C157201] process from the time of the start of combustion until smoulder combustion [APD:glossary/40094] ends.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: For a single leaf, the sum of flame duration and smoulder duration, which is the time from the first visible flame until the glowing phase dies out.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: In wildland environments it will be difficult to measure this trait on an individual taxon; it will instead be a 'community level' trait. Therefore, this trait will generally be used to document rates of fire spread in experimental situations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: For a single leaf, the time from an ignition source contacting the leaf until ignition occurs.
A fire response trait which is the time interval (duration) [PATO:0001309] from a leaf's [PO:0025034] exposure [NCIT:C17941] to a flame [ENVO:01000789] until the leaf ignites [APD:glossary/40040].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: For a single leaf, the time from an ignition source contacting the leaf until ignition occurs.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: In wildland environments it will be difficult to measure this trait on an individual taxon; it will instead be a 'community level' trait. Therefore, this trait will generally be used to document rates of fire spread in experimental situations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Classification scheme of plant resource requirements and tolerances, categorising taxa based on their water, soil nutrient, and soil salinity requirements and tolerances.

An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which categorises plants based on the environmental conditions in which they survive and thrive, including their tolerance of, sensitivity [NCIT:C25201] to, and requirement [NCIT:C25652] for certain resource availabilities [EnvThes:21497], including water [CHEBI:15377] availability and soil [ENVO:00001998] nutrient [CHEBI:33284] content and salinity [PATO:0085001].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Classification scheme of plant resource requirements and tolerances, categorising taxa based on their water, soil nutrient, and soil salinity requirements and tolerances.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match:  Species tolerance to drought [TRY:30] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
close match: Species tolerance to salt [TRY:1254] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Classification scheme of plant flood regime requirements and tolerances, categorising taxa into seven groups based on their germination and growth responses to flood regimes.

An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which categorises plants based on the depth [PATO:0001595], duration [PATO:0001309] and frequency [PATO:0000044] of inundation [SWEET:phenSystem/Inundation] a plant [PO:0000003] is able to tolerate. It incorporates their ability to tolerate or respond to fluctuations in flooding [ENVO:01000710] and drying, including growth [GO:0040007] and seed germination [GO:0009845] responses.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Classification scheme of plant flood regime requirements and tolerances, categorising taxa into seven groups based on their germination and growth responses to flood regimes.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Ellenberg moisture value [TOP779] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Categorical groupings, indicating the length of time a taxon is able to tolerate water-logged soils.

An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which is the duration [PATO:0001309] that a plant [PO:0000003] is able to tolerate water-logged soils, an indication of a plant's sensitivity [NCIT:C25201] to flood [ENVO:01000710] conditions. Soil [ENVO:00001998] is considered water-logged if it is saturated [NCIT:C61427] with water [CHEBI:15377], limiting the plant root's [PO:0009005] ability to respire [GO:0045333] due to a lack of soil oxygen [CHEBI:15379].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Categorical groupings, indicating the length of time a taxon is able to tolerate water-logged soils.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Categorical groupings, indicating the length of time a taxon is able to tolerate being under water.

An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which is the duration [PATO:0001309] that a plant [PO:0000003] is able to tolerate inundation [SWEET:phenSystem/Inundation], an indication of a plant's sensitivity [NCIT:C25201] to flood [ENVO:01000710] conditions.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Categorical groupings, indicating the length of time a taxon is able to tolerate being under water.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Species tolerance to waterlogging [TRY:61] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
close match: Ellenberg moisture value [TOP779] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Categorical groupings, indicating the length of time a taxon is able to tolerate being under snow cover.
An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which is the duration [PATO:0001309] that a plant [PO:0000003] is able to tolerate being covered by snow [ENVO:01000406].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Categorical groupings, indicating the length of time a taxon is able to tolerate being under snow cover.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: close match: Frost tolerance [TOP768] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Maximum salinity tolerated by a taxon, reported as the conductivity of the soil.

An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which is the maximum [NCIT:C25564] soil [ENVO:00001998] salinity [PATO:0085001], reported as soil conductivity [PATO:0001585], that a plant is able to tolerate.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Maximum salinity tolerated by a taxon, reported as the conductivity of the soil.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Species tolerance to salt [TRY:1254] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
related match: Ellenberg salt value [TOP200] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Classification scheme of plant salt-tolerance categories, categorising taxa based on their tolerance of or sensitivity to salty soils, salt spray, or salt water.

An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which categorises plants based on their salinity [PATO:0085001] tolerance [TO:0006001], reflecting the duration [PATO:0001309] and concentration [PATO:0000033] of salt [CHEBI:24866] exposure that a plant is able to tolerate.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Classification scheme of plant salt-tolerance categories, categorising taxa based on their tolerance of or sensitivity to salty soils, salt spray, or salt water.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Species tolerance to salt [TRY:1254] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
related match: Ellenberg salt value [TOP200] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#note.@value: The trait `soil_salinity_tolerance` documents actual soil salinity levels taxa can tolerate. The trait `plant_type_by_resource_use` has some overlapping values, but focuses on terms to describe a plant's overall resource tolerances/requirements, while this trait focuses on terms associated with salinity tolerances/requirements. The trait `plant_tolerance_soil_salinity` offers numeric soil salinity levels a taxon can tolerate.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Classification scheme of plant soil calcium tolerance,  corresponding to its sensitivity to high soil pH. Plants are categorised as either calcifuge (intolerant of basic soils) or calcicole (tolerant of basic soils, such as calcareous sands and limestone derived soils).

An environmental [ENVO:01000203] tolerance [NCIT:C43414] trait which is a plant's [PO:0000003] calcium sensitivity [TO:0000006], corresponding to its sensitivity [NCIT:C25201] to high soil [ENVO:00001998] pH [NCIT:C45997].

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Classification scheme of plant soil calcium tolerance,  corresponding to its sensitivity to high soil pH. Plants are categorised as either calcifuge (intolerant of basic soils) or calcicole (tolerant of basic soils, such as calcareous sands and limestone derived soils).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Species tolerance to CaCO3 [TRY:595] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
related match: Ellenberg reaction value [TOP781] (https://top-thesaurus.org/index)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.@value: Classification scheme of plant fire tolerance, indicating morphological characteristics plants use to survive fire.
A fire response trait indicating morphological [PATO_0000051] features that protect individuals [EFO:0000542] from death [GO_0016265] when a fire [ENVO:01000786] occurs nearby.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Classification scheme of plant fire tolerance, indicating morphological characteristics plants use to survive fire.

@graph.http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#exam: exact match: Species tolerance to fire [TRY:318] (https://www.try-db.org/de/de.php)
